2. Main presentation: More than 2 years ago, after being hit by her father, the patient developed neck soreness, a sensation of compression, and other discomforts. She firmly believed that her nerves were being compressed, which caused her neck discomfort and hand numbness, but did not seek proper medical attention. Three months ago, due to rhinitis, she noticed and visually observed trembling around the nose, became worried about facial nerve damage, and gradually felt physical exhaustion, generalized fatigue, insomnia, nausea and vomiting, palpitations, numbness in the face and hands, could hear a tearing sound from the neck nerves, sharper than the sound of bones. She became anxious and worried that if her nerves broke, she would become dull or enter a vegetative state. Her lifestyle became apathetic, unwilling to wash her face or comb her hair, concerned these actions would lead to nerve breakage. She repeatedly visited the orthopedic and neurology outpatient clinics, with no special findings.
3. Past history and family history: Discovered to have sphenoid sinusitis two years ago, improved after treatment. At age five, suffered from infectious mononucleosis and hepatitis B. Both parents have distant relatives with suspicious psychiatric history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 82 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 121/71 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, speech is clear, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice on the skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distension, trachea is in the midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 82 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness in the abdomen, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes were not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, dress is appropriate, appearance matches age, expression is natural, mood is stable, interaction is passive, friendly towards medical staff, answers to questions are appropriate, attention is focused, speech rate is moderate, tone is calm. Can elicit visceral hallucinations (hearing the sound of nerve breaking), can elicit hypochondriacal delusion (firmly believes her nerve is damaged), affect is coordinated, no anxiety or depressive mood, no abnormal behaviors, orientation, calculation, and comprehension are normal, partially self-caring, lacks insight, and social function is severely impacted.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Cranial and cervical MRI (****** Hospital, 2012.01.11): 1. Round low signal shadow at the anteroinferior part of the C4 vertebral body, considered possibly an enostosis; the rest of cervical MRI plain scan shows no obvious abnormality. 2. Small ischemic foci in both frontal lobes. 3. Inflammation found in left maxillary sinus, bilateral ethmoid sinuses, and sphenoid sinuses; both inferior turbinates slightly hypertrophic. Cranial MRTA (****** Hospital, 2012.02.15): small ischemic foci in bilateral frontal lobes. Both inferior turbinates slightly hypertrophic. MRTA: The distal branch of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery is closely adjacent to the right facial-acoustic nerve, no obvious compression of the left facial-acoustic nerve and bilateral trigeminal nerves. (****** Hospital, 2012.04.05): EEG is normal. Chest X-ray: No obvious abnormalities in heart and lungs. Brain ET: GABA activity elevated, GA activity elevated.

input:
"## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 24 years old, with a long disease course.
2. Main presentation: Over 2 years ago, during university, after a conflict with a classmate, the patient began to experience unexplained fear, unwillingness to study, felt being watched, thought someone wanted to harm him, decreased interest (previously enjoyed internet use but now unwilling even to do so); low mood, unable to feel happy, wanted to sleep all day. The family brought the patient to my department for inpatient treatment. After discharge, the patient continued taking olanzapine 10mg qn but did not attend outpatient follow-up visits. One month ago, the above symptoms recurred and worsened. Six days ago, he was admitted to our hospital for inpatient treatment, but was not comfortable staying; 3 days ago, the family arranged for automatic discharge. The patient's symptoms persisted, so he was re-admitted today for further treatment.
3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy. Denies hypertension, diabetes, or other physical illnesses. Denies history of hepatitis, tuberculosis, or other infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders and history of epileptic seizures. Introverted personality.
4. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 96 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 118/76 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative for examination. No jaundice on skin or mucosa, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea in midline, normal chest shape, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing detected, no cardiac enlargement detected by percussion, heart rate 96 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs, abdomen flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux negative, no pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention is not concentrated, answers to questions are off-topic, voice is dull. Clothing is appropriate, facial expression blank, partial self-care in daily life, passive interaction with surroundings, indifferent towards medical staff and family. Insight is lacking, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations, no illusions. Slow speech, thought form disorder: slow thinking, poverty of thought. Thought content disorder: presence of ideas of reference and persecutory delusions. General knowledge, judgment, and comprehension are normal, calculation ability normal, recent memory impaired, remote memory normal.
6. On 2013-01-04, liver and renal function, electrolytes, blood routine were normal in our hospital; urinalysis showed no significant abnormality. Chest X-ray, ECG, and EEG revealed no obvious abnormalities."

## Medical Record Information
Case Characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 17 years old.
2. Main presentation: 5 years ago, the patient exhibited abnormal speech and behavior without any obvious inducement, claiming to be a member of the "Hacker League"; through the internet, stated that "the Communist Party is the largest mafia"; felt that teachers treated him poorly, classmates were jealous of him and talked behind his back; believed he could read others' thoughts, considered himself highly capable and a genius; was unable to control repetitive thinking. About a year ago, the condition worsened: when reading about a disease, he felt he had that disease; purposefully failed exams; repeatedly performed actions such as swallowing, turning his head, and washing hands—felt these were unnecessary but was unable to control them. At times, felt that life was too exhausting, accompanied by a low mood, and had multiple instances of running upstairs intending to commit suicide by jumping but never acted on the intention, also accompanied by poor sleep. Two months ago, the patient manifested incoherent speech, telling parents "I have a lot of money in an American bank and can get it anytime." One month ago, he became excited, talked excessively, felt energetic, ate less, and slept less. Over 20 days ago, the patient was hospitalized at ****** Hospital, diagnosis unknown. During hospitalization, he was irritable and restless, believed medical staff were deceiving and harming him, was administered "antidepressant toxin, anti-obsessive toxin" medications, showed impulsivity, attacked relatives, ran around and jumped about. During the course of illness, the patient did not experience auditory or visual hallucinations, did not exhibit paranoia, did not suspect people were discussing, controlling, or tracking him, and had no significant loss of interest, inability to feel happiness, or reduction in activity. Upon admission to my department, treated with "Olanzapine, Quetiapine, Chlorpromazine, Benzhexol", the condition was relieved, but the patient still had low mood, irritability, and difficulty falling asleep at night.
3. Past history and family history: The patient generally has average health condition. Denies history of epilepsy and other major systemic diseases, transfusion history, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of mental disorders. The patient is a "left-behind child," has lived at school for a long period and has little communication with parents; from an early age considered academics most important, and is messy in life with poor personal hygiene.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 82 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 120/80 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, speech is clear, and cooperative during examination. Skin and mucous membranes show no jaundice, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal with no widened intercostal spaces, percussion yields clear sounds over both lungs, breath sounds are clear with no crackles or wheezing, no cardiac border enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 82 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat with no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular venous reflux sign is negative, and no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Psychiatric examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers to questions are relevant, voice is calm. Appropriately dressed, expression is natural, partially self-caring, proactively interacts with surroundings, friendly to medical staff and family. Lacks insight, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations, no illusions. Marked anxiety and depressive emotions, speech rate is moderate, no disturbance in thought form; no disturbance in thought content. Common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension are normal, calculation ability is normal, immediate memory is normal, long-term memory is normal.
6. Ancillary examinations: On 2013-04-23, chest X-ray, ECG, EEG, cranial CT, routine blood and urine tests, liver and kidney function, etc. at our hospital showed no significant abnormalities.

"Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is female, 39 years old.
2. She has experienced, over the past 4 years, episodes without obvious triggers characterized by refusal to eat, refusal to speak, poor sleep, stupor, and no urinary incontinence. She was admitted to ****** People's Hospital, underwent EEG and CT with normal results (reports unavailable), received 1 week of internal medicine inpatient treatment (medications unknown), improved and was discharged, then stopped taking medication on her own. Six months later, symptoms recurred, but the family cannot recall any clear trigger. She again presented with refusal to eat and speak, did not seek medical attention, and improved spontaneously after about one week. In the past 4 years, there have been 5 episodes, which, according to family, sometimes appeared after arguments but without significant dispute or aggression, and sometimes after catching a cold. One year ago, during another episode, she had a cranial CT at ****** People's Hospital, which showed no obvious abnormalities. She did not take medication and improved spontaneously after about one week, returning completely to normal. Five days ago, after an argument with her husband, she developed, 4 days ago, another episode of refusal to eat or speak; she was responsive when called and could go to the toilet by herself. EEG at ****** Hospital indicated results within normal range. Routine blood test revealed total leukocyte count 12.95×10⁹/L, neutrophils 11.33×10⁹/L. Family denied history of cough or sputum production. For further diagnosis and treatment, she was admitted to our department for inpatient care.

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 14 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 12 years ago, due to underlying neurodevelopmental abnormalities, the child began to exhibit social withdrawal and emotional dyscontrol behaviors, including randomly discarding objects at home and impulsively touching his own head, accompanied by chronic difficulty initiating sleep. In the recent 4 weeks, symptoms have fluctuated, manifesting as disorganized language expression and difficulty with self-care, occasional episodes of contact conflict and repetitive somatic movements. Past treatment history includes multiple hospitalizations for antipsychotic medications and electroconvulsive therapy, with behavioral issues temporarily controlled but showing recurrent patterns. This time, the patient was admitted via emergency due to medication refusal and occasional impulsive limb actions.
3. Past history and personal history: Since 8 months after birth, the patient began to have seizure episodes, repeatedly and continuously occurring until over 5 years of age, etiology attributed to early abnormal EEG findings. Marked delay in speech acquisition with persistent unclear articulation, overall cognitive function development is below average. No family history of psychiatric disorders is recorded; additional information is unremarkable.
4. Physical examination: Temperature 36.3°C, pulse 75 beats/min, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 124/74 mmHg. The patient is conscious, cooperative in communication, with clear speech and oropharyngeal structures, but language organization lacks obvious logic. Systemic examination shows no organic abnormalities, no jaundice, lymphadenopathy, nuchal rigidity, or positive cardiopulmonary/abdominal signs; physiological reflexes are present and normal.
5. Psychiatric examination: Orientation is essentially intact, but attention is difficult to maintain, and responses lack specificity. Facial expression shows emotional flattening, complete loss of self-care ability with dependence on movement of objects for assistance; emotions are easily provoked, occasionally triggering contact conflicts; significant retardation in cognitive development, unable to cooperate on memory assessment; severe impairment of social functioning and lacks insight into pathological manifestations.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Complete blood count, liver and kidney function, and metabolic indicators are normal. Two EEG examinations both showed abnormal background rhythms. Chest imaging excluded organic changes of the heart and lungs.

English_disease_name: Catatonia associated with another mental disorder
input:
## Medical Record Information
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 17 years old.
Six days ago, while working in a different city, the patient developed cold and fever (exact temperature unclear), followed by gradually emerging bizarre behaviors such as running around randomly, jumping, and making strange faces; whenever music was heard, he would start dancing. Previously fond of playing video games, after onset, some movements and game-related language from gaming appeared; no impulsive aggressive or wandering behaviors noted. The patient was irritable, restless, and became increasingly less verbal, now basically not speaking. After onset, nighttime sleep was nearly absent and food intake decreased. Two days ago, hospitalized at a local county hospital (diagnosis and treatment details unclear; received infusions of levofloxacin, ceftriaxone, etc.), with no symptom relief. Yesterday, he wet his pants; hospitalized for 1 day and discharged today. Since yesterday and today, the patient refused food and appeared weak and powerless. Today, for further treatment, he was accompanied by family to our department for inpatient care.
The patient previously had an introverted personality, worked in a different city prior to illness, working 12 hours a day. Online dating with a girlfriend lasted half a year; the day before onset, the patient's father wanted to introduce a new girlfriend, and after onset the patient said, "I want all the girls."
2. Past medical history: The patient's family denies any history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, hypertension, or diabetes.
Family history: Negative for mental illness.
3. Physical examination: T 37℃, P 60 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 79/61 mmHg. Patient was cooperative. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, multiple scabbed scars present. Neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea midline, normal thoracic shape, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs clear, breath sounds clear, no crackles or wheezing. No cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 60 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. About 5 cm long scabbed wound with redness around the area visible on the right calf.
4. Mental examination: The patient is difficult to engage, does not answer questions, and consciousness status cannot be assessed. Expression is flat, occasionally grimacing with bizarre facial features, and meaningless limb movements. Cannot conduct further examination.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

diagnostic_category: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
English_disease_name: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium, without psychotic symptoms
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 33 years old.
2. Main presentation: 11 days ago, at 38 weeks of gestation, the patient underwent a cesarean section and successfully delivered a female infant. Three days ago, the patient began to experience significant sleep disturbances, characterized by frequent awakenings and early morning waking. At the same time, her mood remained persistently low with an increased sense of hopelessness and emptiness. She actively expressed a lack of interest in infant care or persistent worry about her baby's health and safety. The patient was unable to concentrate, had difficulty recalling daily details, displayed marked fatigue and weakness, and showed changes in appetite with reduced food intake. Recently, she exhibited social withdrawal, neglected personal hygiene, and repeatedly expressed suicidal ideation in her speech. About half a day ago, the patient attempted suicide by jumping from a building, resulting in lumbar vertebral fractures. Consultation with the orthopedics department recommended bed rest.
3. Past history and family history: The patient was previously physically healthy and had no history of psychiatric disorders, including no depressive episodes or chronic anxiety. There was no family history of psychiatric diseases or genetic disorders.
4. Physical examination: Vital signs were stable: temperature 36.6℃, pulse 73 beats/min, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 115/76 mmHg. The patient was alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No obvious abnormalities were found on systemic examination, and no pathological reflexes were elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness was clear, orientation was normal, attention was markedly distractible and unable to maintain focus. Answers to inquiries were relevant but speech was slowed. The patient was disheveled, showed a persistent sad expression, was completely dependent on others for daily living, and had no motivation to interact with medical staff or family, requiring nursing staff assistance for all daily activities. Passive engagement was prominent. Insight was lacking; verbal output and expression were limited. No abnormality was found on assessment of thought content, general knowledge and comprehension were normal, and memory showed no significant impairment. Mood remained in a stably low-energy state, without obvious anxiety, with poor ability to cope with stress, and negative cognition predominated.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Lumbar CT showed fractures of the third lumbar vertebral body and transverse process; routine blood tests revealed a mildly elevated leukocyte count, clinically considered as changes related to traumatic stress response. Repeated interviews confirmed no family conflict, work pressure, or other social-psychological stressors; all symptoms were directly related to the postpartum state.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
## Admission Diagnosis
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 19 years old.
2. Main presentation: According to family members, over the past two years, the patient has gradually developed abnormal behaviors, including repeatedly looking in the mirror, long-term reluctance to communicate actively, and often talking to herself, claiming to be monitored by satellites; symptoms worsened in the past week, manifested as frequent inappropriate laughter, illogical speech, and claiming that topical medications are fluorescent substances and can identify specific people by blinking. The patient persistently avoids social interaction and keeps a distant attitude towards family members. Difficulty falling asleep at night.
3. Past history and family history: History of urticaria treated with loratadine, now recovered. No history of major physical illnesses.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 21 years old, with chronic onset and a relatively long disease course.
2. Main presentation: 1) According to the patient: more than 2 weeks ago, after watching "My Love from the Star," she said the male star in the show liked her, came to see her, and waved to her. She could see him on the balcony and outside the window. She believed the male star was an alien and had special abilities. At night, she felt very happy when thinking about him and was unable to sleep. 2) One week ago, the patient imitated the male star's style, cut her hair short, and wore male clothing. According to her family: the teacher reported that during evening study, the patient suddenly ran out and then returned crying, saying the male star did not come and might not like her. The patient laughed for no apparent reason. She greeted many people and looked out the classroom window to wave hello during lessons. After returning home, she frequently watched from the balcony and felt pleased. She did not sleep at night and was very excited.
3. Past history and family history: More than 10 years ago, she had "viral myocarditis" which has been cured. No history of seizures, epilepsy, or head trauma. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8°C, P 68 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 124/68 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, responds appropriately to questions, speech is clear, and cooperates during examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein filling, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, cardiac percussion reveals no enlargement, heart rate is 68 bpm, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers are appropriate, voice is calm. Dressed appropriately and neatly, natural expression, independent in daily life, actively interacts with surroundings, friendly toward medical staff and family. No obvious emotional depression or elation. Insight is lacking, no auditory hallucinations; other hallucinations present, visual hallucinations, no illusions. Speech rate is moderate. Thought form disorder: none; thought content disorder: no primary delusions (delusional memories), no delusions of reference, no erotomania. General knowledge is normal, judgment and comprehension are normal, calculation ability is normal, recent memory is normal, remote memory is normal. Social function is significantly impaired.
6. Auxiliary examination: (2014-03-28, ****** Hospital) EEG: mildly abnormal EEG, BEAM. Oculomotor assessment: normal. Self-rating scales for anxiety and depression: normal.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:

6. No obvious hallucinations have been found at present.
7. Previous treatment included antipsychotic medication, with symptom relief in the past, but current relapse requires inpatient management.

diagnostic_category: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
English_disease_name: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium, without psychotic symptoms
input: Patient is female, 24 years old. Current symptoms: Since pregnancy 9 months ago, patient began experiencing difficulty falling asleep, frequent dreaming and easy awakening, reduced speech and activity, diminished interest. Three days postpartum, symptoms worsened, manifesting as decreased movement, mutism, refusal to respond, and difficulties with elimination management. In the past 7 years, she has experienced several episodes of depressed mood accompanied by sleep disturbances, each lasting for a short duration, with rapid recovery of social functioning following medication intervention at **** hospital. During these episodes, she occasionally had negative thoughts but did not display any persistent behavioral or physical functional impairment. Psychiatric examination showed clear consciousness and intact orientation, appropriately dressed but passively mute, with a depressed facial expression, decreased activity, and low mood. Social functioning and self-care ability are currently significantly impaired, with limited maternal role fulfillment. EPDS scale score was 15 (assessed on postpartum day 2) at **** hospital, consistent with the time course characteristics of perinatal symptoms.

## Admission Diagnosis
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 32 years old.
2. Approximately 8 years ago, the patient gradually developed abnormal behavior, manifested as emotional instability and difficulties in social interaction. He has undergone diagnosis and treatment with antipsychotic medication at multiple locations, with partial symptom relief but without complete improvement. In recent years, the patient's social activities have significantly decreased, emotional expression has become flat, and he exhibits a tendency towards sluggishness in daily activities, requiring family assistance and supervision for personal hygiene and basic life management.
3. Past history and family history: No special findings.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 85 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 135/84 mmHg. Percussion of both lungs yields clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing heard. No cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 85 bpm, regular rhythm, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes not elicited.

English_disease_name: Dementia due to psychoactive substances including medications
input:
Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is female, 37 years old.
2. Main presentation: 16 years prior to admission, the patient was diagnosed with "epilepsy," manifested by limb rigidity and drooling during attacks, each lasting 2-3 minutes, with attacks occurring irregularly. Four years ago, the patient developed persecutory delusions and auditory hallucinations, accompanied by disorganized behavior, and was diagnosed in ****** hospital with "epileptic psychosis." She was treated with Risperidone, but later reduced the medication on her own, resulting in relapse. Two months ago, she again experienced hallucinations (voices and visions), was hospitalized in my department for treatment, and her antiepileptic and antipsychotic medications were adjusted, resulting in improvement. On the day of discharge, she again experienced fluctuation in her condition accompanied by cough and yellow sputum, and was admitted for further treatment.
3. Past history and family history: 16 years prior to admission, the patient was diagnosed with "epilepsy" and received antiepileptic treatment with carbamazepine and sodium valproate. No special family history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 90 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, with no obvious abnormalities on heart or abdomen examination. Moist rales heard in both lungs, neurological examination is negative. Mental examination: Clear consciousness, poor interaction, generally cooperative with examination, answers questions when asked, responses are appropriate, speech is unclear, unable to conduct in-depth psychiatric examination, lacks insight, and has severely impaired social functioning.
5. Auxiliary examinations: On January 31, 2011, blood concentrations of carbamazepine and sodium valproate were 4.46 ug/mol and 107.9 ug/mol, respectively.

## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 37 years old.

During preoperative examinations for coronary heart disease, a significant decrease in platelet count was discovered. During glucocorticoid treatment, the patient suddenly developed altered consciousness, specifically including inability to concentrate and maintain attention, confusion in daytime orientation (unclear about time and place), accompanied by fluctuating impulsive behaviors during the day such as an intention to jump out of the window and self-injurious actions to the head. The family described sleep interruption with abnormal sensory experiences (roaring sound in the brain). After discontinuation of glucocorticoid medication, the symptoms fluctuated, with persisting partially improved hypokinesia and food refusal behavior.
3. Past history and family history: No special findings.
4. Physical examination: T 37.1℃, P 88 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 137/103 mmHg. Mental examination shows fluctuating alertness, such as inability to focus when responding to commands.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 11 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 6 months ago, due to being misunderstood by classmates about her exam results and having conflicts with them, the patient began to believe that mischievous classmates at school wanted to bully her, felt that classmates were talking about her behind her back, speaking ill of her, and felt isolated. She gradually reported that sometimes, even when going to the bathroom alone, she could hear classmates' voices saying bad things about her, although she could not see anyone at the time. This made her distressed and unable to concentrate in class. However, she only experienced these voices when at school. She was worried that someone wanted to harm her and was unwilling to go out. At the end of September 2010, she visited our department's outpatient clinic and was advised to receive medication, but her family requested observation without medication, and her condition did not improve afterward—she was still unwilling to attend school and continued to claim that classmates spoke ill of her at school and feared being separated from them. At the end of March this year, she visited our department again and was treated with amisulpride 0.2 qn. She was stubborn and unwilling to take the medication, and was admitted for treatment today.
   The patient is naturally timid, sensitive, and suspicious. Since becoming ill, her appetite and sleep have been relatively good. After eating spicy food yesterday, she complained of nausea and mild upper abdominal discomfort this morning, with no fever, diarrhea, or convulsions.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has had poor constitution in the past, frequently caught colds, and had one febrile seizure in childhood. Her cousin has depression.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 70 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 100/60 mmHg. The patient is alert and cooperative during physical examination. The head and facial features are normal, bilateral pupils are equal and round, about 4mm in diameter, light reflex is sensitive, neck is soft and symmetrical. Chest is symmetrical and without deformity, bilateral tactile vocal fremitus is symmetrical, percussion produces clear sound, breath sounds in both lungs are clear, no dry or wet crackles heard. No precordial bulge, no palpable thrill, heart percussion reveals no enlargement, auscultation reveals heart rate of 70 beats/min, regular rhythm, no pathological murmurs heard in any valvular auscultation areas. Abdomen is flat and soft, slight tenderness under the xiphoid process, no shifting dullness on percussion, bowel sounds are normal on auscultation. Spine and limbs show no deformity, muscle strength and muscle tone of all limbs are normal. Physiological reflexes are present, no pathological reflexes elicited. 
Mental examination: The patient is conscious, interactable, appropriately dressed, age-appropriate appearance, orientation is normal, no signs of sensory enhancement or reduction, no illusions or disturbances in perception elicited. Auditory verbal hallucinations, referential delusions, and persecutory delusions can be elicited. No formal thought disorder, expression is natural, affect is relatively flat, no impulsive or bizarre behaviors observed; able to care for herself, no significant decline in academic performance, insight is partially impaired, social functioning is compromised. Memory, calculation, and comprehension abilities are normal.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable

input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 23 years old.
2. 25 days ago, the patient delivered a male infant by vaginal birth. Beginning 17 days ago, she gradually developed emotional instability, with occasionally repetitive speech, impulsive behaviors such as making phone calls to contacts, excessive organization of personal clothing and discarding belongings; continuously engaging in online job searching activities (previously worked as a make-up artist), with some content fabricated, such as overly favorable descriptions of material conditions; self-claims of capability and plans to start a business, with mixed speech content; marked mood fluctuations, easily awakened at night; fixed morning behaviors such as engaging in household cleaning activities. Thirteen days ago, these manifestations became more prominent, and phone calls increased. Six days ago, the family brought the patient to a psychiatric institution for inpatient treatment and prescribed a medication regimen. After ECG abnormalities, the medication was discontinued and switched to sodium valproate, with a recommendation for cardiology evaluation. Before admission, ECG showed characteristics of preexcitation, tentatively attributed to drug effects. For further treatment, the patient was admitted to ****** department tonight, accompanied by family.
    Further history inquiry: patient's family deny any history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, etc. The patient denies history of hypertension. Denies history of diabetes. Denies positive family history of psychiatric disorders.
3. Physical examination: T 37.5°C, P 103 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 115/76 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and cooperates with examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear, no rales, no wheezing; on percussion, no cardiac enlargement, heart rate 103 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs; abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.

input:
Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is male, 35 years old.
2. Main presentation: Beginning more than 10 years ago, the patient started drinking high-proof liquor, almost daily, consuming 500-1000g per day, and rarely ate food while drinking. Over the past four years, after stopping alcohol, he developed burning sensation in the chest, dizziness, generalized weakness, inability to walk, and these discomforts would disappear after drinking. In the last 10 days, after alcohol cessation, on top of the above symptoms, he developed involuntary tremors of the limbs and nausea, but no vomiting. During the course of illness, he experienced difficulty falling asleep, poor appetite, dark yellow urine, and in the past week, passage of brown, mushy, loose stools with foul odor.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has a history of hepatitis B virus infection of more than 10 years; underwent appendectomy for appendicitis in 1997, and right inguinal hernia surgery in 2011, with good postoperative recovery. The patient denies history of hypertension and denies history of diabetes mellitus.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 94 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 120/86 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the examination. Mild scleral jaundice is present but no spider angiomas are seen; no enlarged superficial lymph nodes; neck is supple without resistance or jugular vein distention; trachea is midline; chest contour normal with no widened intercostal spaces; percussion of both lungs produces clear sound; breath sounds are clear; no crackles or wheezing; no heart enlargement on percussion; heart rate 94 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs; abdomen is flat with significant tenderness below the xiphoid process and mild tenderness in the left upper abdomen; no rebound tenderness; the liver is palpable 1 cm below the right costal margin, with firm texture; spleen not palpable; liver-jugular reflux sign negative; no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention focused, answers to questions are appropriate, and voice is calm. The patient is properly dressed, with natural facial expression, partially capable of self-care in daily life, makes active contact with surroundings, and is friendly towards medical staff and family. Insight is intact, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations or illusions. Speech rate is moderate; no formal thought disorders; no content thought disorders. Common sense, judgment, comprehension, calculation, recent memory, and remote memory are all normal.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of alcohol
input:
Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is male, 39 years old, with a short disease course and acute onset.
2. Main presentation: Four years ago, the patient began to drink alcohol excessively, consuming about 500ml of white spirits daily, accompanied by changes in personality, including irritability, anger, and impulsive aggressive behaviors; memory declined. During these four years, the patient attempted to quit alcohol several times, and each abstinence resulted in dizziness, headache, palpitations, and general discomfort, which were alleviated after resuming drinking. Three weeks ago, the patient stopped drinking on his own, and three days ago started to experience auditory hallucinations at night (hearing voices giving him commands); he also had visual hallucinations, seeing many snakes and "thousands of troops and horses" rushing towards him, with whom he "fought," causing insomnia throughout the night. He denies paranoid ideas or persecutory delusions.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s usual health condition is average. Denies any history of epilepsy or other major physical illnesses, blood transfusions, or infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 80 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 90/60 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responds appropriately to questions, speech is clear, and cooperates with examination. Facial complexion is grayish; no jaundice on skin or mucous membranes; no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes; neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention; trachea is midline; chest shape is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces; percussion of both lungs is clear; breath sounds are clear; no crackles or wheezing; cardiac percussion shows no enlargement; heart rate is 80 beats/min, regular rhythm; no murmurs; abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness; liver and spleen not palpated; liver-jugular venous reflux sign is negative; no pitting edema of both lower extremities. Physiological reflexes present; pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, has normal orientation, attention is focused, answers questions appropriately, and appears consistent with his stated age. Clothing is appropriate and clean; facial expression is natural; can care for himself; no abnormal contact observed; insight is partial; mood: tense; illusions present (mistaking dust on the floor for snakes); visual, tactile, and auditory hallucinations present (including command hallucinations). Partial insight; social function is significantly impaired; general knowledge, judgment, comprehension, and calculation abilities are normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable at our hospital.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 17 years old.
2. The patient is a senior high school student. Three months ago, after performing poorly on a physics exam, he returned home and cried inexplicably. Family members repeatedly asked about the reason but he was unable to explain. The next day, he was sent back to school, but soon after, the teacher called to report that the patient was shouting loudly at school and requested that he be taken home. The patient began experiencing auditory hallucinations (hearing voices out of nowhere), frequently talking to himself, feeling that people around him were commenting about him, believing that everyone was paying attention to him, thinking that the school had installed surveillance cameras to monitor him, and believing that others could know his inner thoughts even without him speaking. He felt that he had special abilities, such as being able to hear conversations from a far distance, believed he was a key student being developed by his teachers, and thought he could get admitted into ****** University (normally very self-confident). His suspiciousness markedly increased, suspecting his mother of revealing his privacy to classmates, treating everyone as potential enemies, not acknowledging being ill, and requesting hospitalization to prove his mental health. He is irritable, easily angered, and occasionally shows impulsive behaviors. One week ago, after doing poorly on a math exam, he became low in mood and emotionally unstable, constantly thinking he couldn't get into a good university, was doubtful about the future, felt that he had disappointed his parents and wondered if they could forgive him, and was sensitive and suspicious towards people and things around him—especially evident at 6 PM in the evening. One day ago, these symptoms worsened, so he was admitted to my department for inpatient treatment.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's general health has been average. Denies history of epilepsy and other major physical illnesses, blood transfusions, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5°C, P 82 beats/min, R 22 breaths/min, BP 123/81 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathes steadily, answers questions appropriately, speaks clearly, and is cooperative during the examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distension, trachea is midline, chest wall is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezes, cardiac percussion shows no enlargement, heart rate is 75 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, negative hepatojugular reflux sign, no pitting edema in lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers to questions are appropriate, voice is calm. The patient is appropriately dressed, facial expression is natural, self-care in daily life, passive contact with others, friendly to medical staff and family members. Insight is intact, no auditory hallucinations, no other hallucinations, no illusions. Moderate speech rate, no formal thought disorder, no thought content abnormalities. Common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension are normal, calculation ability is normal, recent and remote memory are normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1) The patient is female, 21 years old. Six years prior to admission, the patient was hospitalized due to childish behavior and emotionally uncontrolled actions, presenting with crying, agitation, and abnormal social interactions. During hospitalization from 2010.10.19 to 2010.11.05, improvement was noted after treatment with Risperidone and the patient was discharged. Subsequent outpatient follow-up and medication adjustments were performed several times due to functional fluctuations related to developmental delay. 2) More than 1 year ago, emotional instability worsened, with irritable crying, occasional social conflicts such as scratching parents, hospitalized again from 2015.05.08 to 2015.05.21. After medication adjustment, emotions remained uneven, with occasional purposeless silly laughter. 3) Distinct relapse noted one week ago, frequently crying without reason, making disorganized vocalizations or throwing temper tantrums, sometimes venting emotions by slapping soft pillows, occasionally complaining of chest tightness and discomfort. Sleep is normal but occasionally cries at night. Current medication includes Olanzapine 10mg in the morning and 20mg in the evening, among others.

Past history and family history: Ischemic-hypoxic history in infancy and childhood, history of convulsions before age 3. Appendectomy for appendicitis performed 10 years ago without complications.

Physical examination: Vital signs stable, clear consciousness, breathing regular, partially appropriate answers to questions, speech relatively clear, cooperative during the physical examination. No abnormal findings on superficial examination. Cardiac and respiratory exams normal; abdomen soft without tenderness.

Mental examination: Orientation intact, attention adequate, partially incoherent expression. Age-appropriate clothing, initiates friendly contact, partially dependent on assistance for daily life. Poor insight, presence of simple repetitive movements. Poor general knowledge, judgment and calculation ability markedly deficient.

Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 27 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 10 years prior to admission, after hospitalization for bilateral calf fractures, the patient experienced a sudden episode of general discomfort, including accelerated heartbeat and near-death reaction, which resolved after symptomatic treatment. Since then, without obvious triggers, recurrent episodes have occurred. During these episodes, symptoms include palpitations, sweating, rapid breathing, tingling sensations, and fear of death, without a predictable or fixed trigger. Repeated consultations and examinations, including ECG and cardiac tests, have all been normal, but the patient remains concerned about recurrence and shows avoidant behavior towards daily activities such as grocery shopping or TV programs. During intervals between episodes, the patient returns to normal, and symptoms ease upon seeing a trusted person or being near ****** hospital. Mental state, appetite, and sleep are normal, with stable weight.
3. Past history: Underwent cholecystectomy in 2009. No history of substance abuse. Allergic to one medication. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: Temperature 36.5°C, pulse 99 beats/min, blood pressure 111/78 mmHg, conscious. Mental examination showed intact orientation, anxious mood without delusions, cooperative attitude, preserved insight. Social functioning is impaired only during episodes.
5. Auxiliary examinations: All results verified as normal.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 23 years old.
2. Main clinical manifestations: Over 2 months ago, the patient began experiencing significant pressure, resulting in sensitivity and suspiciousness. She felt that both family members and outsiders were trying to harm her, believed that someone was monitoring her through her mobile phone, was unwilling to go out to work, felt unsafe, and suspected that someone was following or attempting to kill her. While playing games, she felt as though she had entered the game character and was very worried that dangerous situations from the game would occur in real life, being concerned for her own safety. During the course of illness, there were no auditory hallucinations and no decline in interest.
3. Past history: Over 2 years ago, the patient felt stressed from studying and subsequently developed low mood and decreased interest. She then sought treatment at ****** Hospital and, after medication (specifics unknown), her mood improved.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 80 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 125/78 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing smoothly, answers questions appropriately, speech is clear, and cooperates with the physical examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance and no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal in shape, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs yields clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing. No cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 80 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes are not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention is concentrated, answers questions appropriately, voice is low. Appropriately dressed, exhibits a frightened expression, able to care for herself in daily life, passive interaction with the environment, indifferent to medical staff and family members. Lacks insight, has persecutory delusions, disturbances in thought content. diagnostic_category: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
English_disease_name: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium, with psychotic symptoms
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 36 years old, recently presenting with emotional abnormalities and delusional symptoms.
2. Main presentation: 20 days ago, after a miscarriage, the patient suddenly began to hear voices that were not there, suspecting that her husband was having an affair, that others were monitoring her life, and that they intended to harm her. Ten days ago, the patient acted impulsively and went out late at night to a friend's house. Later, during the surgical abortion procedure at ****** Hospital, she was firmly convinced that someone was poisoning her. Three hours ago, the police found the patient in the area with safety risks and notified her family to pick her up. During this period, the patient experienced significant mood fluctuations, had suicidal thoughts but did not carry them out.
3. Past history: In 2023, the patient underwent an induced abortion at ****** Hospital. Fifty-four months ago, she had a cesarean section. Denies history of trauma, epilepsy, chronic diseases, or infectious diseases. Menstrual history: amenorrhea for 3 months. Family history: mother exhibits talking to herself.
4. Physical examination: Temperature 36.7°C, pulse 82/min, respiration 19/min, blood pressure 140/100 mmHg. Conscious, responsive, cooperative, no abnormal findings on general examination. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations all negative for positive findings. Neurological physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, attention mildly distracted. Clothing is roughly appropriate but disheveled; emotional expression is angry and anxious, impulsive and irritable. Passively hostile towards staff, lacks insight. Marked auditory hallucinations, referential delusions, persecutory delusions, and jealousy delusions elicited; abnormal behaviors include tendency for collision and running away. In-depth conversation is limited; overall presentation consistent with a postpartum stress reaction pattern.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable.

These complaints were not taken seriously and no treatment was given. 7 months ago, she believed there were surveillance devices in her bedroom; she thought people across from her were talking about her; she suspected her husband's family wanted to frame her. Patient is male, 21 years old.
Case characteristics:
Main presentation: About 8 days ago, the patient suddenly developed abnormal speech and behavior without obvious inducement. Initial manifestation included panic attacks, emotional agitation accompanied by crying and shouting for help, and attempted to jump out of a car. Subsequently, the patient exhibited slowed movements, required supervision in daily activities, and responded slowly to questions. The symptoms showed significant diurnal fluctuation, especially worsening at night, with episodes of suddenly awakening and sitting in a daze. Concentration was decreased, the patient had difficulty in orientation to environment, and provided confused descriptions of time and date. No evidence of hallucinations or delusions was observed.
Past history and family history: The patient is generally healthy, with no history of epilepsy, major physical illnesses, infectious diseases, or family history of psychiatric disorders.
Physical examination: Vital signs are stable (T 36.2℃, P 80 bpm, R 20 rpm, BP 112/70 mmHg), no abnormal findings throughout the body, internal medicine signs are normal.
Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear but attention is difficult to maintain, orientation to time and place is deficient, and short-term memory is impaired. The patient has an indifferent facial expression but is emotionally irritable; interaction is passive, lacking spontaneous speech. Insight is impaired, common sense and comprehension are reduced, and social functioning is significantly limited.
Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable.

English_disease_name: Catatonia associated with another mental disorder
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 11 years old.
2. Main presentation: Starting more than 6 years ago, the patient developed recurrent left-sided chest and abdominal pain accompanied by weakness in both lower limbs, each episode lasting over 10 days, with poor treatment efficacy. Nine months ago, the patient began experiencing auditory hallucinations (details unclear), persecutory delusions: believing there were two people coming with sticks to hit him. Subsequently, the patient developed seizures: tonic stiffness in the left limbs progressing to generalized tonic stiffness, facial muscle twitching, no response to painful stimuli, aggressive behavior, with 1-2 episodes of urinary incontinence, each lasting from several seconds to up to 30 minutes, occurring 10-25 times per day, with some variability in each episode; unable to recall the situation after each episode. The patient was admitted to my department for symptomatic treatment with olanzapine. About one month after discharge, seizure episodes recurred; the patient visited ****** Central Hospital and was treated with sodium valproate, topiramate, and piracetam, but seizures persisted. Three months ago, the patient underwent surgical treatment at ****** Hospital and was treated with vanillin, epilepstop, compound phenobarbital sodium bromide tablets, anxiolytic sedative pills, and mengshi rolling phlegm tablets. There was a period of over one month postoperatively without recurrence, but the aforementioned symptoms reappeared. Seven days ago, the patient underwent "acupoint injection therapy" again at ****** Hospital, and after returning home had episodes of abnormal psychiatric and behavioral manifestations, including frequent falling to the ground, biting others, vocalization, unexplained crying or laughing, complaints of palpitations, heat sensation, and talking about ghosts. Today, after another acupoint injection therapy, similar manifestations recurred about ten minutes after treatment, with increased frequency, leading to admission to my department for further treatment.
3. Past history and family history: Denies history of major somatic diseases, denies positive psychiatric, epilepsy, and genetic disease history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 92 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 122/72 mmHg. Patient is conscious, approachable, cooperative with physical exam, neck is soft and symmetrical. Chest is symmetrical, auscultation reveals clear breath sounds in both lungs, no dry or moist rales. No precordial bulging, no tactile fremitus, heart percussion borders not enlarged, auscultation heart rate   beats/min, regular rhythm, no pathologic murmur in any valve auscultatory area. Abdomen is flat and soft, no tenderness, no shifting dullness on percussion, normal bowel sounds on auscultation. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited. Mental examination: Consciousness clear, entered the ward, approachable, orientation intact, emotional state coordinated; elicitable auditory hallucinations (patient reports hearing male and female voices saying “kill you”); elicitable suspicious relational delusions (patient reports seeing two people stalking him); abnormal behavior noted, such as sudden mutism and biting others during the mental exam, lasting about 1 minute, followed by recovery of clarity and ability to walk back to the ward unaided; lacks insight, impaired social functioning.
5. Auxiliary examinations: (2010-9-15) Dynamic EEG: abnormal. Cranial MRI: bilateral hippocampal FLAIR signal increased.

## Admission Diagnosis

Case characteristics:

Main presentation: 12 years ago, the child developed paroxysmal convulsions following low-grade fever, which improved after antibiotic treatment; after the age of 2, the child experienced repeated convulsive episodes, accompanied by significant decline in intellectual function and social adaptability. The child has delayed speech development, is unable to clearly describe events, and cannot independently complete daily life tasks; one month ago, during hospitalization in my department, the patient was treated with Risperidone, Seroquel, and electroconvulsive therapy leading to improvement and discharge, but 2 days ago emotional agitation and abnormal behavior recurred, characterized by incoherent speech and impulsive actions without obvious cause. diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 18 years old.
2. More than 4 months ago, the patient began to feel significant academic pressure, resulting in personality changes, spending the entire day playing games, poor personal hygiene, a lazy lifestyle, difficulty concentrating, decreased learning efficiency, and declining grades. Gradually, there was reduced verbal expression and avoidance of social activities. The family did not pay attention to these changes, resulting in failure in the college entrance examination; the patient is currently studying in a regular university as a freshman and has a desire to pursue a medical career. In the past year, there have been expressions of unrealistic ideas and overestimation of his own abilities. The patient believes family members hinder his academic development, complains about family relationships, harbors deep resentment, reduces external communication, has poor hygiene habits, emotional indifference, is passive in social interactions, and occasionally displays uncertainty in behavior. Recently, contact with the family has been unstable. Since the onset of illness, appetite has been normal, consciousness is clear, mental state is suboptimal, sleep is suboptimal, bowel movements are normal, urination is normal, and body weight has no significant change.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has a history of hepatitis B. The patient's family denies a history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, and other related conditions. The patient denies a history of hypertension and diabetes.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7°C, P 68 bpm, R 20 breaths/min, BP 106/76 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing is stable, answers questions appropriately, speaks clearly, and cooperates with the examination. No jaundice of the skin and mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate 68 bpm, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat with no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen are not palpable, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower extremities.

Clothing is messy and dirty, facial expression is indifferent, personal hygiene management is poor, lacks initiative in social interactions, and avoids others. Insight is impaired. Thought content reflects unrealistic ambitions, with no fixed beliefs. Understanding of common sense is inconsistent, emotional response is dull, and interest is lacking.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 33 years old, with a long course of illness and an insidious onset.
2. Main presentation:
(1) One year ago, 'prostatitis' led to excessive health anxiety, persistent nervousness, and difficulty falling asleep; despite multiple self-regulation attempts, the patient was unable to control ongoing worries about his physical condition.
(2) Half a month ago, worries about sleep quality rapidly worsened. After taking 'Xide 10mg tid and Shuxu 50mg qn,' sleep slightly improved. Fifteen days ago, due to increased anxiety, the patient revisited for follow-up and was switched to 'Xide 10mg tid and Zopiclone 1 tablet qn,' but saw no improvement; persistent anxiety continued to disturb the patient, causing him to discontinue medication on his own. After stopping medication, difficulty falling asleep worsened, but there were no other significant emotional changes.
3. Past history and family history: One year ago, the patient had 'prostatitis,' which has been cured. No special family history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8°C, P 67 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 107/69 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive and coherent in speech, cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea midline, chest shape normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear, no crackles, no wheezing, heart borders not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 67 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, both lower limbs show no pitting edema. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention is distracted and difficult to focus due to frequent worries; appearance matches age, appropriately dressed, facial expression appears anxious and tense; self-care ability intact; insight is basically complete; mood is characterized by persistent restlessness and inability to relax; irritable, often feels muscle tension; denies hallucinations or illusions. Social function is partially impaired due to persistent tension; general knowledge, judgment, comprehension, and calculation abilities are normal.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 38 years old.

In recent years, when encountering unpleasant events such as work setbacks or marital quarrels, the patient would exhibit emotional agitation, sobbing-like behavior, impulsive and self-harming tendencies such as attempting to jump off a building, hitting his head with a brick, smashing glass, etc. He denies suspiciousness, talking to himself, laughing to himself, or hearing imaginary voices. input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 36 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 3 months prior to admission, the patient developed abnormal mental behavior without obvious cause, including speaking incoherently and claiming that someone wanted to harm him, accompanied by nervousness and fear. The symptoms worsened paroxysmally. The patient visited multiple hospitals for treatment, but the symptoms did not significantly improve, and the patient developed reduced speech, difficulty in pronunciation, gradual decrease in limb movement, difficulty in swallowing, and fever (highest temperature 38.5°C). The patient subsequently visited our hospital's neurology department and was diagnosed with "viral encephalitis." After treatment with "dexamethasone and mannitol," mental and behavioral abnormalities persisted. Later, the patient was transferred to the psychiatry department for treatment. Our department administered Seroquel, alprazolam, and sodium valproate for symptomatic control of neuropsychiatric symptoms, and vitamin B1, mecobalamin, monosialotetrahexosylganglioside sodium, and other neuro-nutrition and symptomatic support therapies. The patient's condition improved compared to before and he was discharged. Half a day ago, the patient suddenly became emotionally agitated, argued with family members, and again exhibited abnormal mental behavior; the patient was then sent by family for hospitalization in our department.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's family denies history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, etc. The patient denies history of hypertension and diabetes.
4. Physical examination: T 36.6°C, P 80 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 112/59 mmHg. The patient's consciousness is clouded, breathing is steady, answers questions appropriately, speech is clear, and cooperates with physical examination. 5. Mental examination: The patient's consciousness is clouded, orientation is impaired, attention is not focused, answers to questions are inappropriate, voice is low. The patient is appropriately dressed, with a blank facial expression, partial self-care, passive interactions with the environment, and indifferent toward medical staff and family members. Lacks insight; form of thought: none; content of thought: none. Abnormal general knowledge, abnormal judgment and comprehension, abnormal calculation ability, abnormal recent memory, abnormal remote memory.

CSF biochemical test: chloride 129 mmol/L ↑, CSF protein 0.43 g/L ↑. Blood glucose 6.60 mmol/L ↑. Cranial CT showed no obvious abnormality. On 2012-09-11: dynamic EEG: abnormal electroencephalogram.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 29 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 7 years ago, without obvious cause, the patient developed poor concentration, unable to listen attentively when spoken to, repeatedly asking others what was said, requiring family members to urge her several times before she would eat or do laundry, and she would spend a long time repeatedly washing clothes and bathing; she needed to repeat her words several times to feel at ease. Over 5 years ago, after a traffic accident resulting in nasal bone fracture, these symptoms worsened; she became unable to feel happy, repeatedly checked doors and windows, compulsively repeated tasks, took a long time to respond to questions, and insisted on perfecting her answers before speaking. She sought treatment at the local hospital and was given “Paroxetine (up to 3 tablets daily) and Alprazolam tablets” with no obvious improvement and worsening of the above symptoms. More than 3 years ago, the patient developed slowed reactions, taking a long time to answer questions, and if interrupted, insisted on finishing her previous thoughts before continuing. Before speaking, she frequently looked down to think about what she wanted to say; every sentence took a long time to complete and needed to be repeated many times. The items she placed could not be moved by others; if moved, she became agitated and insisted they be placed according to her preferences to feel at ease. When asking her spouse a question, she hoped for the answer “en”, but if her spouse said “yes”, she would repeatedly ask until the answer was “en.” The spouse’s position and posture needed to remain unchanged for the conversation to continue; any movement interrupted the dialogue and required the spouse to return to the original position and posture before continuing. While shopping, she would repeatedly look at the signs before entering the store. The patient is aware these behaviors are unnecessary but cannot control them. During this period, the patient had multiple outpatient visits at ****** Hospital, was treated with citalopram 40mg qd and fluvoxamine 50mg bid, with no obvious improvement. To seek relief, she was admitted to ****** Hospital today.
3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy, the patient denies history of hypertension and diabetes. Family reports her grandaunt has a history of psychiatric disorder, with details unclear.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 78 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 115/79 mmHg. Consciousness is clear, breathing steady, responsive to questions, clear speech, cooperative during examination. No jaundice of skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is centered, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing; heart border not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 78 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs; abdomen flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable; liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention focused, answers appropriate, voice calm. Dressed appropriately, natural expression, partially self-caring, actively interacts with surroundings, friendly toward medical staff and family members. Insight is intact, no auditory hallucinations. Speech slow. Thought form: no disturbance; thought content: no disturbance. General knowledge normal, judgment and understanding normal, calculation ability normal, recent memory normal, remote memory normal.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable at ****** Hospital.

## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:

2. Main presentation: More than 5 months ago, the patient developed repeated handwashing and involuntary thinking, sometimes talking to himself. If he did not say it out loud, he would feel agitated. He is afraid of touching his own genitalia, afraid of physical contact with others, has low mood, feels worried, fearful, and tense, and has poor sleep. 4 months ago, he was seen in the outpatient clinic of our department and was considered to have a "schizotypal mental disorder," and was treated symptomatically with "Sertraline, Olanzapine, and Artane," with slight improvement in symptoms. He has been followed up long-term in the outpatient clinic of our department. One month ago, medications were adjusted to "Bocisyn 5mg bid, Zoloft 50mg qd, 100mg qn, Xide 10mg bid" for symptomatic treatment, but there was no significant improvement in the patient's condition, and he felt that living was very painful.
3. Past history and family history: One year ago, the patient was treated at ****** Children’s Hospital for "left hand fracture" and was cured. The patient’s general health condition is average. Denies history of epilepsy and other major physical illnesses, history of blood transfusion, and infectious disease history. Denies family history of mental illness.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 80 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 120/68 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during physical examination. No jaundice of the skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest configuration is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 80 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema of both lower limbs.
