Medical_record_information: 1. The patient is male, 33 years old, with insidious onset and a long course of disease. 2. Main presentation: Four years ago, the patient developed persistent low mood, decreased interest, and sleep disturbance at night. Two years ago, the patient felt his symptoms worsened, sought medical attention outside of the hospital, and was considered to have mood disorder symptoms. Symptomatic medication was given but the efficacy was not satisfactory. 3. Past history and family history: Twenty years ago, the patient was injured by knife wounds (five sites) during a fight, received more than 40 stitches, and fully recovered after treatment with no sequelae. 4. Physical examination: T 36.3°C, P 70 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 133/91 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and is cooperative during examination. No jaundice on skin and mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, no enlargement of heart borders on percussion, heart rate 70 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, hepatojugular reflux sign is negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Involuntary tremor of both hands, normal muscle strength and tone. Physiological reflexes present, no pathological reflexes elicited. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is concentrated, answers to questions are appropriate, appearance matches age. Dress is appropriate, facial expression is natural, partially self-care in daily life, partial insight, low mood, no auditory hallucinations, no other hallucinations, no illusions. Social function is partially affected, partial insight, common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension are normal, calculation ability is normal. 6. Auxiliary examinations: Tremor graph of right gastrocnemius muscle shows muscle tremor rhythm of 6-7 Hz. Gastroscopy shows chronic antral gastritis with erosion and duodenal bulbitis. Cardiac color Doppler ultrasound shows localized regurgitation at mitral, aortic, and pulmonary valves. Cranial MRI suggests a possible dotted ischemic lesion in the right frontal lobe. No obvious abnormalities were found on chest CT, renal color ultrasound, abdominal ultrasound, or cervical vascular ultrasound.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 20 years old.
2. Over 1 year ago, the patient developed insomnia and early morning awakening without obvious triggers. He stopped medication by himself, which again led to insomnia. According to his parents, progressive memory decline began around 1 year ago, with occasional inaccurate details when recalling childhood events. In the past 5 months, repeated reminders and supervision were needed for washing and eating, mood was unstable and easily irritated; when required to hurry, his speech became rude but there were no aggressive behaviors. Symptoms worsened in the past 3 days. Throughout the course of illness, negative or suicidal thoughts were denied. The family sought hospitalization for diagnosis and treatment.
3. Past history and personal history: No special findings.
4. Physical examination: T 37.2℃, P 82 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 110/68 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing is stable, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and is cooperative with the physical examination. No jaundice of skin and mucous membranes; no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes; neck is supple without resistance; no jugular vein distention; trachea is centered; thorax normal; no widening of intercostal spaces; percussion of both lungs is clear; breath sounds are clear; no crackles or wheezes heard; cardiac borders are normal; heart rate 82 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs; abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable; hepatojugular reflux negative; no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present; no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear; temporal orientation is mildly confused and inaccurate; attention can be maintained; answers are relevant but voice is low. Dress is appropriate; affect is flat; needs assistance in daily life; shows lack of interest in surroundings. Insight is absent. Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 15 years old. 2. Main presentation: Three weeks prior to the high school entrance examination, the patient developed decreased attention and reduced interest, with occasional social avoidance, but self-care ability remained basically normal. About one week ago, the patient suddenly became energetic, with a marked increase in speech and accelerated thinking; persistent sleep duration was less than 4 hours per day without feeling tired, she actively formulated high-intensity study plans with blind confidence, and during periods of elevated mood, often spoke faster, jumped between topics in a fragmented manner, exhibited restlessness and impulsive behaviors such as arbitrarily intervening in others' affairs. According to family, the state of excitement has lasted for more than 5 days. One day ago, emotional fluctuation shifted to marked irritability and a brief episode of agitation was triggered by a minor conflict. Emergency coagulation profile: PT 20.8 s, INR 1.70, APTT 156.4 s, TT 24.9 s, Fbg 1.37 g/L; cranial CT showed no obvious abnormalities, thus admitted to hospital with diagnosis of "coagulation disorder." 3. Past history and family history: The patient's general health status is average. Denies epilepsy and other major physical diseases, history of transfusion, or infectious diseases. Mother in the family was diagnosed with dysthymia during adulthood. 4. Physical examination: Vital signs stable, clear-minded but easily goes off-topic during conversation, speech is clear, refuses detailed physical examination. No abnormalities detected in skin, heart, lungs, or abdomen; limbs move freely. 5. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation intact, attention is easily distracted by the environment, clothing is tidy but claims "no need for grooming," facial expressions are rich and lively, emotional tone is generally euphoric with a tendency to irritability, denies hallucinations and delusional experiences, describes recent "burst of inspiration." Behavior includes increased purposeless walking, occasionally slaps table impatiently if opinions are not accepted, partial impairment in self-awareness. 6. Auxiliary examinations: Coagulation dysfunction; routine blood test: WBC 11.5×10^9/L; emergency liver and renal function tests and myocardial enzyme profile revealed no significant abnormalities.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 38 years old.
2. Main presentation: Relatives recall that the patient had a period of elevated mood about one year ago, lasting approximately five days, characterized by excessive self-confidence, talkativeness with increased speech rate, flight of ideas, and reduced sleep to less than three hours per day, but with abundant energy; recently, after quarreling with colleagues, the patient gradually became emotionally depressed over the course of two weeks, expressing guilt by saying 'I have committed a crime' and 'I would rather sacrifice myself,' with a marked decrease in interest, unwillingness to interact with others, feeling ashamed, and stating the need to apologize to others, pacing back and forth at home, and unable to rest at night. Family members mentioned that the patient's mood fluctuations have recently intensified, occasionally urinating on herself when provoked, without symptoms such as fever or cough. The patient exhibited increased psychomotor agitation and aggravated insomnia, along with impulsive behaviors such as hitting family members, and no obvious delusion or hallucination was observed.
The patient reported that her mood has been persistently low since two weeks ago, unable to feel happy, accompanied by sleep disturbance and fatigue.

3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy, no family history of psychiatric disorders.

4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 109 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 128/82 mmHg. The patient was alert but emotionally irritable, poorly cooperative, limb muscle strength and tone were normal, and pathological signs were negative.
Mental examination: The patient showed flight of ideas, rapid and jumping speech, but the content centered around self-blame; impulsive behavior, repeated mentioning of colleague's name and singing short tunes even when restrained; attention was distracted during examination due to emotional agitation, but no obvious thought disorder or delusional content was noted.

5. Auxiliary examination: Routine blood test showed elevated total white blood cell count at 14.38*10^9/L↑, decreased lymphocyte percentage at 11.30%↓, indicating mild inflammatory response.

## Admission Diagnosis

"## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
The patient is female, 20 years old. Seven years ago, without obvious inducement, she began to experience low mood, significant reduction in interests, and was completely unable to enjoy daily activities, with repeated suicide attempts including wrist cutting, jumping from a building, and drug ingestion. She occasionally appeared irritable and restless in noisy environments. She has long-term significant sleep problems, including difficulty falling asleep, easy awakening and early morning awakening, each time feeling miserable upon waking. During the course of illness, there were several distinct episodes of elevated mood, each lasting more than a few days, during which she felt energetic, had significantly increased self-confidence, reduced need for sleep, racing thoughts that were hard to interrupt, and actively participated in multiple previously uninteresting activities, though she occasionally felt slight discomfort in her hands. She denied abnormal experiences such as hearing voices or persecutory delusions. She described improvement after treatment. She denied significant physical diseases, infectious diseases, and family history of psychiatric disorders. Physical examination showed the patient was alert, vital signs were stable, and all systems were normal without lesions. Mental examination showed normal orientation but distracted attention; clothing appropriate, expression fluctuated; partial insight; emotional presentation alternately depressive and briefly elevated. Social function was partially impaired, judgment and common sense were normal. EEG performed on July 5, 2016 showed no obvious abnormalities."

Medical_record_information:

Two-plus weeks ago, the patient frequently described signs of her husband having an affair. One-plus weeks ago, antidepressant treatment was administered with poor efficacy, and the patient showed slow reactions.
Since the onset of her illness, the patient experienced no obvious physical discomforts, was alert and mentally sound, had significant mood fluctuations, normal sleep, normal bowel and bladder functions, and stable weight.

English_disease_name: Catatonia associated with another mental disorder
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
The patient is female, 33 years old. 
Past history: General health condition is average. Denies any history of epilepsy or other major physical diseases, blood transfusions or infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders, but the father had unspecified psychiatric or behavioral abnormalities. 
Personal history: The patient has a strong, stubborn personality and insists on doing things her own way. She is the youngest among multiple siblings in her family, and has two sons.

Clinical presentation: The initial onset was 16 years ago at age 17, characterized by sudden collapse without an obvious trigger, presenting as whole-body rigidity and immobility, unresponsive to questions, without convulsions or tongue biting. Symptoms resolved after brief observation. Since then, attacks recurred 1-2 times per year, mainly as mutism and immobility, occasionally accompanied by tearing or localized muscle twitching. After marriage and childbirth at age 22, the frequency of attacks significantly decreased, until symptoms recurred repeatedly over the past 4 years. Recently, the attacks intensified; onset increased 1 month ago, and 5 hours prior to admission, she collapsed suddenly at the time of consultation and was immediately sent to the emergency department. The patient reports no experiences of anxiety, depression, paranoia, or mania.

Physical examination: Body temperature 36.5°C, heart rate 78 beats/min, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 118/86 mmHg. Conscious but slow to respond; skin and lymph nodes normal throughout; neck is supple with no resistance; heart, lung, and abdominal examinations reveal no abnormal findings; no edema in the lower extremities; physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes are absent.

Mental examination: Conscious but in a marked stuporous state—no spontaneous movement, maintaining a fixed position at the table for over 30 minutes, ignoring nurses’ wake-up commands; intermittently repeats single arm flexion and extension behavior, approximately 10 times; gaze is vacant during questioning, facial expression is absent, unable to be further evaluated.

Auxiliary examinations: EEG and cranial CT performed on April 7 and April 27, 2013, at ****** Hospital showed no abnormalities.

Medical_record_information:

These symptoms persisted for several months. More than one month ago, the patient became emotionally elevated, excited at night, spoke more, showed significantly increased self-confidence, was very interested in various activities, actively participated in pranks, made detailed plans for the future, and exhibited one impulsive destructive behavior. During this period, sleep requirement decreased, and his mental energy was abundant.

Medical_record_information:

She was hospitalized at ****** Hospital for treatment, during which her condition gradually improved after receiving antidepressants and physical therapy, and she was discharged. Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 29 years old. The onset was insidious, and the course of disease has lasted more than two years. 2. Main presentation: Over the 2+ year course, the patient has experienced episodes of mood fluctuation—sometimes brief periods of excitement, increased speech, repetitive language, occasional abnormal cheerfulness, talking and laughing to herself, expressing ideas about becoming a fashion designer and feeling capable, with occasionally increased desire to shop. During periods of low mood, she cries alone, is unwilling to engage in social contact except with her husband, stays at home and does not go out, shows no interest in daily matters, neglects management of her clothing store, and pays little attention to her child, leading to a lazy lifestyle and rejection of parental concern. Mood fluctuations have resulted in functional impairment. 3. Past history and family history: The patient’s family denies history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, etc. The patient denies history of hypertension and diabetes. No significant psychiatric illnesses are recorded in the family history. 4. Physical examination: T 36.5°C, P 75 bpm, R 18 bpm, BP 112/65 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers questions appropriately, speaks clearly, and is cooperative in exam. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, jugular veins are not distended, trachea in midline, normal chest shape, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds clear, no crackles or wheezing, no cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 75 bpm, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema of lower limbs. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers to questions are appropriate. Speech is normal. No formal thought disorder; no content thought disorder. General knowledge, judgment, comprehension, and calculation ability are normal. Recent and remote memory are normal. Insight is lacking. Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 20 years old.
2. One month prior to admission, after an argument with classmates, he developed difficulty concentrating and memory deterioration. He gradually showed difficulty learning new information, such as forgetting recent conversations or doctor’s instructions; the next day, he felt dizzy and slow to respond; his insight significantly declined, and he was unable to handle academic tasks. After a brief course of local treatment, his mental status partially recovered, but memory issues persisted. Three days before admission, sleep disorders worsened, and he complained of “headache, dizziness, inability to concentrate”; family members noted signs of anxiety. The patient repeatedly complained that one year ago he experienced similar physical discomfort, but the main problem was long-term memory decline.
3. Past and family history: Patient’s general health is average. Denies history of epilepsy, major physical illnesses, transfusion, or infectious diseases. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: Temperature 37.1℃, pulse 83/min, respiration 20/min, blood pressure 136/80 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, speech is clear, cooperative during examination. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation testing shows inability to accurately state current date and time; attention is somewhat scattered, answers to questions often miss details; appearance matches stated age. Dressed neatly, mildly depressed facial expression; poor self-care, needs others to remind him of daily matters, initiates contact but memory interference is frequent; overall mood is low, no obvious hallucinations or delusions; social functioning is severely impaired, academic pursuits impossible; insight is partial, often misremembers details of recent events; frequently confuses people’s names or places.
6. Auxiliary examinations: On 2015-11-28, cranial CT plain scan at ****** Medical University Second Affiliated Hospital showed no abnormalities. On 2015-12-08, EEG at our hospital was within normal range; brain ET showed neurotransmitter abnormalities but no definite organic cause.

English_disease_name: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium, without psychotic symptoms
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 32 years old.
2. Main presentation: Approximately four weeks after cesarean section nine months ago, the patient began exhibiting persistent depressed mood and worsening feelings of hopelessness, accompanied by a lack of interest and energy in caring for the infant and neglect of daily household chores and personal hygiene on occasion. However, the patient reports moments of brief interest in her hobbies such as listening to music. Over time, irritability and agitation intensified. Three months ago, upon doctor's recommendation, she started taking antidepressant medication, but efficacy was poor. In the past month, she has had significant sleep disturbances along with recurrent thoughts of hopelessness. Two days ago, she experienced strong suicidal ideation and expressed thoughts about jumping from a building.
3. Past history and family history: The patient usually enjoys average health and denies any history of mood or anxiety disorders. No history of epilepsy, major physical illness, blood transfusion, or infectious diseases. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 72 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 116/74 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathes steadily, responds appropriately with clear speech, and is cooperative during the examination. Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 
1. The patient is female, 36 years old. 
2. Three days ago, after her father's liver cancer surgery, the patient began experiencing poor sleep, difficulty falling asleep, repeated awakenings at night, with only 2-3 hours of sleep each night, and increased speech with jumping topics. One day ago, the patient called her family, requesting to return home before 12:00 noon, and claimed she was going to open a supermarket. On the way home, the family noticed the patient's speech was illogical, repeatedly expressing “You are all acting to deceive me,” and similar content. After returning home, when asked if she recognized her family members, the patient appeared confused, spoke incoherently, and was unable to respond normally. The family administered sleeping pills orally, which were ineffective; the patient developed a panicked mood, mistaking a dog’s leg used for exorcism for a cat and screamed in fear. She then fell to the ground, talked to herself facing into space, and claimed relatives would die soon. Symptoms worsened at night and slightly alleviated during the day. Treatment at ****** Community Health Service Center with diazepam injection and IV therapy was ineffective. The patient continued drinking large amounts of water and urinated multiple times indiscriminately, and was subsequently transferred to this hospital. After outpatient assessment, she was admitted to the hospital. 
4. Physical examination: T 37.7℃, P 82 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 106/61 mmHg. The patient was in a state of confusion, breathing was steady, responses to questions were irrelevant, speech was fragmented, pronunciation was clear but content was incorrect. Physical examination cooperation was poor. Neck was supple without resistance, heart and lung findings were normal, no abdominal tenderness, physiological reflexes were present, and no pathological reflexes were found. 
5. Mental examination: Consciousness was clouded, orientation was poor, and patient was uncooperative in identifying time, place, or person. Attention was scattered, unable to focus on questions. Emotional fluctuation was intense, shifting from panic to indifference. Voice varied greatly in volume. Dress was neat but contact with surroundings was passive, and the patient was resistant toward medical staff. Thought process was disorganized, with obvious perceptual disturbances; illusions and hallucinations were prominent, expressing erroneous ideas such as relative crisis, but content was variable and without fixed delusions. General knowledge, judgement, calculation, and distant and recent memory could not be assessed. Insight was impaired. 
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 26 years old.
2. More than 7 years ago, the patient became withdrawn and spoke little, was unwilling to go out, and had communication barriers with his parents. Occasionally, he experienced auditory hallucinations (hearing sounds out of nowhere), suspiciousness about being discussed by others, exhibited bizarre behaviors, and compulsive actions. He was treated at ****** Youth Mental Health Center, and gradually received regular treatment with Vespidone and Paroxetine for more than 1 year, after which the above symptoms disappeared. Over 1 month ago, the patient stopped taking Paroxetine for 3 days. The patient reported occasionally hearing vague sound fragments and sometimes muttering to himself in a low voice. Five days ago, during an outpatient visit, there was marked mood fluctuation, and he had a physical altercation with his mother.
Since the onset of this episode, the patient’s appetite has been normal, consciousness clear, mental state acceptable, sleep satisfactory, urination and defecation normal, and no significant change in body weight.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 100 bpm, R 20 breaths/min, BP 133/90 mmHg. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers questions appropriately, voice is neutral. Clothing is appropriate and tidy, facial expression slightly monotonous, partially capable of self-care, significant avoidance in social interactions, maintains distance with others, attitude toward medical staff is proper. Insight is partial; occasionally claims to have special perceptual abilities but reports being unable to confirm their reality, and has no systematic delusional ideas. Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 29 years old. 2. Main presentation: For more than 6 years prior to admission, the patient experienced persistent low mood following stressful life events, with long-term feelings of heaviness and depression and a marked decrease in interest in daily life, as well as poor sleep. In the past, she worried about environmental safety but did not form fixed beliefs, manifesting only as sensitivity in interpersonal relationships. She performed mild cleansing behaviors daily, which did not affect her pace of life. She had unhappy experiences but no specific self-harming actions. Six years ago, due to emotional problems, she visited ****** Hospital and was treated symptomatically with Anshenning and Citalopram 1# qd for 6 months; after symptom improvement, she stopped medication on her own. Six months ago, following mood fluctuations, she visited the outpatient clinic at our hospital, reporting persistent mood issues that had somewhat improved, maintaining a meticulous personality, and did not report obvious anxiety; after adjustment to Citalopram 60mg qd, Venlafaxine 75mg bid, and Azaleptin 2.5mg qn, her condition stabilized. Over a month ago, dose reduction led to worsening emotional distress. During the illness course, no hallucinations, elevated mood, or thought disorders were observed. The patient is currently hospitalized for treatment. 3. Additional history inquiry: The patient's family denies history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, or hemiplegia. The patient denies history of hypertension or diabetes. 4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 75 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 90/70 mmHg. General knowledge, judgment, and memory are normal. 6. Auxiliary examination: None available at our hospital currently.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
Case Characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 24 years old.
2. Eight years ago, when the patient was in the third year of junior high school, he experienced significant academic pressure and had a habit of masturbation. He developed slow reactions, memory decline, low mood, reduced interest in activities, slothfulness in daily life, and difficulty falling asleep. These symptoms lasted for one month, were neglected, and untreated, and gradually improved. Subsequently, his mental state remained suboptimal, with occasional emotional fluctuations. Ten months ago, due to disorganized behavior and impaired speech, he was admitted to my department. An affective episode was initially considered, and he was treated with Divalproex, Olanzapine, and Haloperidol, resulting in partial symptom improvement before discharge. After discharge, medication adherence was irregular, and his psychological state somewhat improved. More recently, the patient presented again with abnormal signs, including disorganized speech, occasional inexplicable crying or laughing, distracted attention, and incoherent thinking; during communication with family members, his logic was markedly erratic. In conflicts, he is easily irritable and exhibits unexplained venting behaviors such as object smashing.
    The current state is under continued observation, appetite is normal, the patient is alert, overall mental state is fair, sleep is poor with prominent early awakening, finding it difficult to fall back asleep after waking at 4 am. Bowel and bladder function are normal, and there is no change in weight.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's overall health status is average. Denies any history of epilepsy or other major physical illnesses, blood transfusion, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: Temperature 36.2℃, pulse 80 beats/min, respiratory rate 21 breaths/min, blood pressure 112/78 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steady, responses during conversation are partially off topic, speech disordered, and cooperates with the examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes; no palpable enlargement of superficial lymph nodes; neck is supple without resistance. Trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no dry or moist rales and no wheezing on auscultation. Heart rate 78 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs in any valve area. Abdomen is flat and soft, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen non-palpable, no edema in both lower limbs.
    5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, attention is scattered, responses often diverge from their intended meaning, monotone speech. Appropriately dressed, facial expression is intermittently apathetic, maintains self-care in daily life, participates passively and slowly in social interactions. Insight is incomplete, evident commanding auditory hallucinations; no other perceptual disturbances. Average speech rate, showing loose associations and scattered thinking. No unreasonable ideological content. General knowledge is adequate, judgment and comprehension are preserved, calculation and memory basically intact.
    6. Auxiliary examination: 2012-05-04 cranial CT: no substantial abnormality in brain parenchyma. Mild local inflammation in the left ethmoidal sinus.

Medical_record_information:

Patient's family history description: Two years ago, the patient developed abnormal speech and behavior, poor sleep, excessive excitement and talkativeness, tension and fear, and felt that others were talking about him. On December 21, 2011, the patient visited ****** Mental Health Center, and his condition improved after treatment. After discharge, the patient's mood remained unstable, believed that having been hospitalized impacted his social interactions, and for a long time stayed at home being lazy, sleepy, unwilling to take medication or feigned taking medication. Three months ago, when the family built a new house, he would help with tasks when in a good mood, but would avoid tasks when not in a good mood. Ten days ago, the patient requested to go out for work but was unstable, sometimes claiming to be competent, sometimes doubting coworkers' evaluation of him. In the past three days, his emotional fluctuations intensified, at times exaggerating his ability, at times blaming himself for poverty, but the symptoms were mild and intermittent. The family noticed his repeated changes and sent him to our outpatient clinic today; the patient was afraid of hospitalization and was anxious while waiting; he was admitted for treatment under the diagnosis of 'mood instability disorder.'

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 25 years old. 2. Main presentation: The patient developed poor sleep 2 months ago, mainly complaining that her worries are related to sudden discomfort, unwilling to communicate or participate in social activities, and explicitly stated during consultation that she had no loss of interest or depressed mood. One month ago, she suddenly experienced palpitations, profuse sweating, whole body tremors, and rapid breathing, which relieved after rest. Two days ago, she suddenly experienced several episodes of dyspnea, facial pallor, marked hand tremors, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting without obvious triggers; each episode lasted about 10 minutes before relieving. Examinations at ****** Hospital and ****** District People's Hospital showed that routine labs, thyroid function, electrolytes, and ECG were normal; in MRI of the spine and hip joint, only hip joint effusion was seen, no special treatment was given. One day ago, she received astragalus and Shenmai infusions for 2 days at a community hospital, but the number of episodes did not decrease. Today, due to worsening fear of symptoms, the patient came to the hospital voluntarily, reporting high anxiety due to recurrent episodes and intentionally avoiding public places. She was admitted to the hospital for further assessment and treatment. 3. Past history and family history: She had myocarditis 10 years ago (recovered), a 2-year history of kidney stones with occasional low back pain not treated, and underwent appendectomy 10 years ago. 4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 88 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 115/74 mmHg. The patient is alert and cooperative, breathing smoothly, and responsive to questions. Skin and mucous membranes show no jaundice, superficial lymph nodes are not enlarged, neck is supple with no resistance, trachea is midline, chest is normal, both lungs show clear percussion and breath sounds, no crackles or wheezing, heart rate is 88 bpm, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat and soft with no tenderness or rebound pain, liver and spleen not palpated, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Auxiliary examinations: On 2014-06-07, ECG at ****** Hospital showed no abnormalities; on 2014-06-10, SCL-90 at our hospital: 278 points, reflecting symptom-related distress; ET: 5-HT and some neurotransmitters decreased; EEG sensory threshold test was normal; comprehensive examinations ruled out cardiac, pulmonary and other somatic disease sources, no evidence of other psychiatric disorders was indicated.
