Several days later, the patient experienced paroxysmal mental confusion, scattered and incoherent speech, slow chewing of food, and brief sleep episodes while eating. The patient left home without apparent reason and, upon awakening multiple times, was found lying elsewhere with multiple contusion injuries from falls; afterwards, the patient reported vague but unclear memories of leaving home. The family noticed that the patient urinated in bed multiple times, and when changing clothes for him, his eyes were vacant and he showed little response. Brain CT and EEG were done in ****** Hospital Neurology Department with no abnormal findings.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s general health is described as average. Denies history of drug abuse, epilepsy or other major physical illnesses, blood transfusion, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of mental illness.
4. Physical examination: T 36.3℃, P 78 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 118/78 mmHg. No jaundice on skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest wall is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, percussion of cardiac borders shows no enlargement, heart rate 78 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. ## Case Characteristics

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 19 years old.
2. Main presentation: Five years ago, the patient developed dizziness and fatigue, suspected he had a serious illness, and underwent various examinations, all of which showed no abnormalities. However, he continued to believe he was suffering from a fatal illness. Subsequently, he experienced low mood, lack of interest in activities, moved and spoke little, was unwilling to participate in outdoor activities, and often felt emptiness in life. During this period, his lifestyle was sluggish; he did not cut his hair, did not bathe, had poor appetite, poor sleep, but was still able to attend school, and his academic performance did not decline. During this period, he self-administered traditional Chinese medicine for conditioning with poor efficacy. Ten months ago, the above symptoms worsened, so he visited the outpatient clinic of my department, and was considered to have "schizotypal disorder." Symptomatic treatment was given with Zoleptil, Artane, and Baishike, but the patient was uncooperative with treatment. His family took him home for further management, with poor results.
3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy, no family history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 84 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 109/76 mmHg. Case characteristics:

2. Main presentation: 
   (1) Over 4 months ago, after returning home, the patient gradually developed a lackadaisical lifestyle, manifested as a reversal of sleep-wake cycles, reluctance to go out, but still able to eat and take care of himself proactively.
   (2) Over 1 month ago, after catching a cold, the patient presented with abnormal speech and behavior, was unable to continue working, and had one incident of banging his head against the wall.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 25 years old.
2. Main presentation: Three years ago, after taking heroin once, the patient developed insomnia, dizziness, and fatigue. Subsequently, he gradually noticed symptoms of memory decline and distractibility. He sought medical treatment at an outside hospital and was given medication; during the period of medication, his cognitive dullness worsened. After stopping the medication, residual attention problems and language expression difficulties remained. Two days ago, the attention disorder intensified, accompanied by talking to himself, staring blankly, silly laughter, significantly decreased calculation ability, and nighttime sleep difficulties such as trouble falling asleep, easy awakening, and frequent dreaming. In daily life, the patient reported that he requires more time to complete tasks at work but can maintain basic independent living.
3. Past history and family history: Over 10 years ago, history of right leg fracture due to a fall, otherwise unremarkable. Father has schizophrenia.
4. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 96/min, R 20/min, BP 144/92 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, speech is slightly slow, and cooperates during the examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs yields clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no rales heard, no wheezing sounds, cardiac percussion shows no enlargement, heart rate is 96/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux sign is negative, no pitting edema of both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.

The patient is neatly dressed, with natural expressions, able to care for himself, interacts passively with surroundings, friendly to healthcare staff and family. Partial insight present, no hallucinations or delusions detected. Speech rate is moderate. Thought form: no disturbance; thought content: no disturbance. General knowledge is normal, judgment and comprehension are mildly reduced, calculation ability is abnormal (standard MMSE test score: 22), recent memory is abnormal (standard test indicates mild impairment in the memory domain), remote memory is normal. ADL scale evaluation shows mild abnormality, reflecting reduced efficiency in daily tasks.
6. Ancillary investigations: Outpatient in our hospital: Electroencephalogram is normal. ET: Relative power of 5-hydroxytryptamine, dopamine, norepinephrine, and excitatory neurotransmitter phase 6 is decreased (suggesting dysregulation of excitatory-inhibitory balance in the brain). Cognitive assessment report shows objective impairment in executive function and language domains.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 19 years old.
2. More than 1 year ago, the patient began to experience marked recent memory impairment. The patient reported difficulty remembering newly learned information or conversations, such as the names of people just met or daily arrangements. He often complained that his mind was blank, leading to poor concentration, and sometimes forgot tasks while working and wandered around aimlessly, but each time he was able to return on his own. Nighttime sleep was poor, with difficulty falling asleep, and occasionally he would wake up in the middle of the night with profuse sweating. Emotional fluctuations occurred easily, including increased irritability and anxiety, reduced social interactions, and occasional weakness in both legs. He was unable to perform at work, self-reporting frequent forgetting of details due to memory problems, which affected his job performance. Recent memory has significantly deteriorated, making it difficult to persist at work. Three months ago, he sought symptomatic and supportive treatment at the local hospital to improve memory issues, but relief was not significant. Later, he visited our hospital, where potential memory and cognitive difficulties were initially considered. Over two months ago, the above memory issues worsened again, with the decline in memory severely affecting daily activities, and thus he was admitted to our hospital today for further evaluation.
3. Past history and family history: Medical record of consultation three months ago due to memory problems. The patient's grandmother has a history of similar forgetful behavior but did not seek hospital treatment, possibly related to age-associated cognitive changes in the family. The patient's parents are cousins, indicating consanguineous marriage, and no other special findings.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 82 beats/min, R 22 breaths/min, BP 117/75 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers questions appropriately, speech is clear, and is cooperative with the examination. No jaundice on skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes throughout the body, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs reveals clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, no enlargement of the cardiac borders on percussion, heart rate 82 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, emotionally excitable but with no signs of emotional disorder. Has difficulty concentrating, responses in conversation are slower than before, but answers are appropriate. Contact with others is passive, clothing is suitable and tidy. Memory impairment is prominent, especially in temporal orientation, as the patient is unable to accurately report dates or locations, and sometimes describes inconsistent recent events to compensate for memory gaps. Marked decrement in recent memory affects self-management, but no perceptual disturbances or abnormal thought patterns are present. Social functioning is severely limited, with significant impact on family and occupational domains.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 28 years old.
2. Main presentation: Over 1 year ago, the patient developed slow reactions, became a miner and was often late for work without apparent reason, frequently forgot work tasks, was addicted to the internet, communicated with others online but forgot the details afterwards, became estranged from family, exhibited a withdrawn personality, spoke little, with markedly reduced communication, but could still persist in work for more than half a year. Two months ago, due to forgetting an important appointment, his condition worsened, facial expression became dull, had difficulty recalling recent events, spent excessive time on daily activities like washing his face, occasionally got lost while walking, wandered in place, lived in a clearly negligent manner, did not change clothes or wash for a long time, and became completely dependent on family supervision for daily living. One month ago, he had trouble writing, and his handwriting became slanted. One week ago, he stopped eating and drinking throughout the day, claiming not to remember the feeling of hunger.
3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy, with cervical spondylosis for over a year, treated with minimally invasive procedure with satisfactory effect. Denies major physical diseases and history of infectious diseases. Denies family history of infectious or hereditary diseases.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 78 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 112/69 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, responses appropriate, speech clear, cooperative with examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck supple, non-resistant, no jugular vein distention, trachea at midline, chest wall normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs reveals clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles, no wheezing; heart borders not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 78 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no tenderness, no rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, liver-jugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema of both lower limbs. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, poor orientation to time, unable to state current date and location accurately, attention cannot be focused, answers questions relevantly but with slow recall. Inappropriately dressed, expression indifferent, completely dependent on family for daily care, reduced active interaction. Significant memory impairment, poor learning ability for recent events, frequently fabricates daily events to fill memory gaps, such as incorrectly describing previous day's meals. Lacks insight, does not report hallucinations or illusions. Speech is slow, thought content centers on memory loss, judgment and comprehension abilities are normal, calculation ability is normal, remote memory is relatively preserved but details are vague.
6. Auxiliary examination: Head CT at ****** People’s Hospital, ****** City, ****** Province shows no obvious abnormality in brain parenchyma.

diagnostic_category: Schizophrenia or other primary psychotic disorders
input:
"## Medical Record Information
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 24 years old.
2. At age 13, the patient exhibited reluctance to attend school due to social discomfort; even after his parents sent him to school, he still had difficulty adapting and eventually studied at home. Subsequently, while living at home, the patient gradually became more quiet and spoke less, often staying alone in his room. He needed reminders from family members to eat. Communication with family was limited, the patient seldom took the initiative to contact classmates, and preferred to be alone. Ten years ago, he was seen at ****** Hospital in ****** Province, cranial CT was unremarkable, and no systematic treatment was carried out. Five years ago, he began regular follow-up in the Department of Psychiatry of our hospital, and his symptoms improved with antipsychotic medication, allowing for self-care in daily life. Over the past six months, the patient has often talked or smiled to himself while telling stories or interesting things alone in his room. He feels discomfort and nervousness in crowded places when going out and occasionally exhibits irritability in his mood.
3. Physical examination: T 36.3℃, P 83 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 112/83 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing stable, answers questions appropriately, has clear speech, and is cooperative during examination. No jaundice in skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea midline, chest is normal, no widened intercostal spaces. Percussion of both lungs reveals clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing heard; cardiac borders on percussion are not enlarged, heart rate is 83 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
4. Mental examination: The patient is conscious and oriented, answers questions appropriately, and has a calm tone. Dress is appropriate, facial expression is natural, and daily self-care is relatively intact. Communication with others is passive but friendly, and attitude towards medical staff is good. Insight is fairly good. No auditory hallucinations or other hallucinations, no illusions. Speech rate is moderate; at times the patient's emotional response lacks congruence. General knowledge, judgment, understanding, calculation, and memory are normal.
5. Auxiliary examinations: currently unavailable."

"Medical_record_information:

Main presentation: More than 17 years ago, the patient gradually developed memory decline and decreased attention without obvious triggers, accompanied by slowed movements, disorganized living habits, and decreased social initiative. He has been on long-term treatment with Bocisyn, clozapine, sulpiride, and other medications, with some improvement in symptoms after regular medication use. Currently, he occasionally experiences slowed verbal responses and relaxed facial expressions when alone, is partially self-sufficient in daily living, takes extra time for actions, has weakened memory, and requires more time to think over simple tasks.

Dressed appropriately and neat, facial expression is calm, partially self-sufficient in daily life, communicates passively and less with surrounding people, no hallucinations or delusions, no abnormal changes in thought form or content. General knowledge is within normal range, judgment and comprehension are slightly weak, calculation ability is poor, recent memory is impaired, remote memory is preserved.
6. Auxiliary examination: ECG on admission (2016.08.23) showed no obvious abnormality."

## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 25 years old.
2. Two years prior to admission, the patient developed periodic mood instability without obvious triggers, characterized by increased talkativeness and irritability during manic phases, and decreased interest and fatigue during depressive phases. The mood fluctuations have caused significant impairment in social and occupational functioning. During the course of illness, the patient was hospitalized at ****** Hospital of the People's Liberation Army, where antipsychotic medications, mood stabilizers, and electroconvulsive therapy proved effective; however, the condition relapsed repeatedly, with no remission periods lasting longer than two months. One month ago, mood symptoms recurred. After admission to my department, the patient was treated with Qiye Shen'an Tablets, Seroquel, Depakine Extended Release Tablets, and received 7 sessions of electroconvulsive therapy, after which improvement was observed and the patient was discharged. Over the last four days, mild mood fluctuations recurred, presenting as slightly increased speech and irritability, but without persistent restlessness or significant impulsive behaviors.
3. Past history and family history: One month ago, gastroscopy at our hospital indicated a history of chronic superficial gastritis. No other major physical illnesses or family history of psychiatric disorders were reported.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 97 bpm, R 19 breaths/min, BP 124/77 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice in skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest configuration is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing. No cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 97 bpm, rhythm is regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental status examination: Patient is conscious, oriented, has poor attention, but answers questions appropriately, voice slightly loud, appearing consistent with stated age. Clothing is appropriate for the season, facial expression appears mildly tense due to irritability, partially self-caring in daily life, passive in interaction, with partial insight. The mood state is predominantly irritable with occasional brief episodes of euphoria, without hallucinations or delusions. Social functioning is significantly impaired; behavior is mildly restless but not agitated, with partial insight. General knowledge, judgment, comprehension, and calculation abilities are normal.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable at our hospital.

English_disease_name: Dementia due to diseases classified elsewhere
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 34 years old.
2. Main presentation: One month ago, the patient was hospitalized for “severe hepatitis B” at ****** Second Hospital in ******. Twenty-three days ago, the patient developed a generalized rash during plasma transfusion, which resolved after treatment with “Phenergan.” Twenty-two days ago, while receiving 10% sodium chloride, the patient suddenly developed symptoms of upturned eyes, foaming at the mouth, limb rigidity, and loss of consciousness. Immediate administration of “Diazepam” led to symptom relief and normal speech and behavior after recovery. The following day, the patient gradually developed speech difficulties, reporting “my mind is clear, but I can't express myself,” and showed childish behaviors such as puckering lips or pouting when unsatisfied. Daily living was basically self-sufficient, but the patient reported poor recall of recent events and details of conversations with others. MRI of the head at the outside hospital revealed small ischemic foci in bilateral frontal lobes. Vasodilators and hyperbaric oxygen therapy were given by neurology, but no significant improvement was observed, and daily activities gradually became limited. Ten days ago, cognitive function began to continuously decline. After psychiatric consultation, it was considered that speech expression disorder and behavioral abnormalities were obvious. Oral amisulpride was ineffective; mild liver function abnormalities were found upon review, and the patient was discharged. Five days ago, due to worsening cognitive impairment and functional deficits, the patient was admitted to the psychiatric department of our hospital through the diagnostic outpatient clinic.
3. Past and family history: The patient’s general health is average. Three months ago, she experienced psychological trauma, including business failure and family problems.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4°C, P 96 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 103/84 mmHg. Conscious, steady breathing, responses are vague, poor cooperation during examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no lymphadenopathy, supple neck without resistance, chest percussion clear, breath sounds clear, no cardiac enlargement, heart rate 96 beats/min, regular rhythm, abdomen soft and flat without tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Conscious, unable to fully describe current time and place, appearance matches age, appropriately dressed, expression is fearful, completely dependent on others for daily life, poor contact. Attention is difficult to sustain and affects conversation; speech content is scant; patient repeatedly reports poor recent memory and difficulty managing daily living skills; marked mood fluctuations, no irritability or hallucinations reported; behavior has become passive, social contact is reduced. Lacks insight; common sense, judgment, and executive function are significantly impaired.
6. Auxiliary examination: Head MRI at outside hospital (****** Second Hospital) suggested small ischemic foci in bilateral frontal lobes.

English_disease_name: Dementia due to diseases classified elsewhere
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 27 years old.
2. Four days ago, while crossing the street, the patient was struck from the side by a sedan and thrown, sustaining multiple injuries to the body. Outpatient medical records from ****** First People's Hospital in ****** District documented: "Clear consciousness, no visible cranial deformity, both pupils are equal and round, diameter 0.3cm, sensitive to light reflex; right zygomatic area shows congestion and edema, local tenderness, no palpable subcutaneous bone fracture or displacement." The patient refused further examinations and requested transfer to a higher level hospital for treatment. The patient exhibited significant mood swings, irritability, or fearful withdrawal, has disturbed sleep, complains of dizziness and weakness during the day, reports frequent forgetfulness and difficulty finding words when speaking, with limited verbal expression; exhibits agitation and impulsive behaviors when emotionally irritable, such as requesting family members to handle her, and demonstrates poor understanding and misjudgment of others' intentions.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has generally average health. Denies history of epilepsy and other major physical diseases, blood transfusion, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 89 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 105/68 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steady, answers relevantly, speech is slightly unclear, and is uncooperative during physical examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes; right zygomatic area of the skin is ecchymosed; no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes; neck is supple and without resistance; no jugular vein distention; trachea is midline; chest shape is normal; no widening of intercostal spaces; percussion of both lungs is resonant; breath sounds are clear; no crackles or wheezing; percussion boundaries of the heart are not enlarged; heart rate 89 beats/min; regular rhythm; no murmurs; abdomen flat; no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness; liver and spleen not palpated; hepatojugular reflux sign negative; no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation partially impaired, attention not focused, answers are brief and impoverished, appearance matches age. Wearing appropriate and clean clothes, facial expression alternates between anxiety and fear, partially limited self-care in daily life, partially cooperative contact, emotionally irritable and unstable; behavior is agitated and impulsive, poor general knowledge and comprehension, difficulty handling complex problems.
6. Auxiliary examinations: On December 18, 2011, at ****** Medical University First Affiliated Hospital, cranial CT showed: left parietal subcutaneous hematoma, no intracranial abnormalities. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed no abnormalities; X-rays of both shoulder joints, pelvis, both knees, and lumbar spine showed no signs of fracture.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of alcohol
input:
"Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is male, 39 years old.
2. Main presentation: Eight years ago, the patient began to drink alcohol daily over a long period, consuming about half a jin (~250ml) of strong spirits per day, with significant dependence on alcohol, but was still able to maintain normal life and work. One month ago, after attempting to reduce alcohol intake, the patient developed abnormal speech and behavior, exhibited self-harming conduct and bizarre actions, expressed to his spouse concerns about the safety of meals, refused to return home or to work, and showed incoherent speech such as perceiving external threats (e.g., fearing the Earth would explode and needing to escape, mentioning surveillance and defensive behaviors). Sleep was significantly reduced, with almost no sleep during the night before hospitalization. Initial evaluation at an outside hospital considered alcohol-related problems; after treatment with 'Shusi and Olanzapine,' symptoms alleviated and the patient was discharged. However, outside the hospital, mood was unstable and behavioral adaptation was difficult, leading to another hospital visit.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's general health is average. Denies epilepsy, major somatic diseases, history of blood transfusions, and infectious diseases. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 86 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is conscious, breathing is steady, answers appropriately to questions, speech is clear, and cooperates with physical examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no palpable superficial lymph node enlargement, supple neck without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no intercostal space widening, lung percussion is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezes, no cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 86 bpm, regular rhythm, no murmur, abdomen flat, no tenderness or rebound pain in the abdomen, liver and spleen not palpable, negative hepatojugular reflux sign, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, but attention is easily distracted, communication is relevant, and appearance is consistent with age. Appearance is tidy, facial expression appears tense, can basically care for self in daily life, shows increased passivity in interactions, lacks full insight, emotion tends toward blunting, and there is significant impairment of social function.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable in our hospital."

English_disease_name: Dementia due to diseases classified elsewhere
input:
"## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 26 years old.
2. Four days before admission, the patient's girlfriend observed difficulties in daily activities, such as frequently making mistakes when buying groceries or cooking, and obvious memory decline—often forgetting the location of items; the patient showed increased but disorganized movements, reduced sleep, and a flat affect. One day before admission, the patient became restless, spoke more but with disorganized and unclear content, such as repeatedly reciting meaningless phrases like 'I serve the people, sell medicine with conscience'; when asked about his motives, the patient expressed emotions through gestures but could not clearly explain his intentions; his mood was impulsive, he refused to work or go outside, lost all ability for self-care, and the persistent excitement affected sleep. Because of the patient's withdrawal and loss of daily living abilities, family and girlfriend brought the patient to ****** Medical University Second Affiliated Hospital Neurology Department for diagnosis and treatment. Examinations showed: routine blood tests were unremarkable; cranial MRI revealed punctate ischemic lesions in the left centrum semiovale and right parietal lobe; the doctor recommended transfer to a psychiatric specialty, so the patient was brought to ****** Hospital, where EEG was unremarkable, and he was admitted to my department as an outpatient.
3. Past history and family history: The patient suffered from encephalitis in 2009, resulting in cognitive dysfunction, which improved after treatment and discontinued medication for 2 years. The patient denies any history of hypertension or diabetes.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5°C, P 80 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 115/80 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing is steady, answers are brief but relevant, speech is clear, and he is cooperative during examination. General examination shows no abnormal findings: skin and mucous membranes are not jaundiced, no lymphadenopathy, neck is soft with no resistance, heart and lung percussion is clear, no abdominal tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, no edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, but attention cannot be sustained; answers are sparse and expression difficult, such as word-finding difficulty. Dress is casual and season-appropriate, affect is flat, fully dependent on others for daily life, and lacks interest in the surrounding environment. Insight is poor, no hallucinations or illusions. Speech is slow, thinking is retarded, logic is loose, no obvious delusional content. Common sense and judgment are significantly impaired, calculation ability is markedly reduced, recent memory is severely damaged, and remote memory is abnormal.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Routine blood tests showed no abnormalities; cranial MRI revealed punctate ischemic lesions in the left centrum semiovale and right parietal lobe; EEG was unremarkable."

diagnostic_category: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium
English_disease_name: Mental or behavioural disorders associated with pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium, with psychotic symptoms
input:
"Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 24 years old.
2. More than 1 month ago, after the birth of her 3-month-old child, the patient developed a series of discomforts. In the past week, she has experienced restless sleep and emotional instability. Three days ago, after the child contracted a respiratory tract infection, the patient's symptoms intensified, manifested as excessive excitement, talkativeness, disorganized and incoherent thinking, increased activity, irritability, repeatedly describing her feelings during the 8th month of pregnancy and perceiving abnormal fetal movements. Local attempts were made to sedate her. Today, she was admitted for further examination and treatment due to loss of behavioral control.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s family denies any history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, and other such conditions. The patient denies any history of hypertension or diabetes.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4℃, P 80 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 108/87 mmHg. The patient is conscious, breathing steadily, responds appropriately to questions, speech is clear, and cooperates with the examination. No jaundice on the skin and mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes throughout the body, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no intercostal space widening, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no rales or wheezing heard, cardiac border is not enlarged on percussion, heart rate is 80 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, hepatojugular reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is relatively clear, orientation is normal, attention is distracted, speech often off-topic and tone is rather high-pitched. Appearance and clothing are relatively untidy, emotional fluctuations are marked, and she is highly dependent in daily life, appearing tense and hostile when communicating with medical staff. She is not aware of her own problems and does not report auditory hallucinations. Speech is rapid, with obvious disturbances in thought form, and the content is disorganized and lacks logic, with strong conviction in her belief of being pregnant. General knowledge is vague, judgment and comprehension are generally normal, calculation ability is normal, remote and recent memory are not obviously abnormal.
6. Auxiliary examination: On 2013-12-19, cranial CT in our hospital showed no obvious abnormalities."

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of unknown or unspecified psychoactive substances
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 29 years old.
2. Main presentation: Seven years prior to admission, the patient repeatedly exhibited irritability, suspiciousness, and increased vigilance induced by methamphetamine use. After multiple drug withdrawals, the patient’s mood fluctuated easily and social interactions significantly decreased. Seven months ago, under life stress, the patient relapsed with symptoms of anxiety, emotional instability, and impulsivity, such as occasional head-banging, and he reported that auditory echoing worsened under stress, leading to interpersonal withdrawal and loss of occupational function. All symptoms were directly linked to methamphetamine use, with no evidence of independent psychosis.
3. Past and family history: The patient’s general health had been average. Denies history of epilepsy, other major physical diseases, blood transfusions, or infectious diseases. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 78 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 114/75 mmHg. The patient is clear-minded, breathing steadily, answers appropriately, has clear speech, and cooperates with the examination. No jaundice on skin or mucous membranes, no superficial lymph node enlargement, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal without widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, heart borders are not enlarged on percussion, heart rate is 75 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, hepatojugular reflux negative, no pitting edema in lower extremities. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, oriented, answers questions appropriately, and attention can be concentrated but is easily disturbed by anxiety. Appropriately dressed, expression anxious and tense, self-care in daily life is limited. The patient’s cognition is clear, self-reported symptoms are directly triggered by methamphetamine use, and he understands the consequences of the substance. Emotions are characterized primarily by chronic anxiety, irritability, and agitation. When asked about past experiences, the patient describes perceptual abnormalities such as auditory phenomena mostly occurring transiently during periods of stress or drug withdrawal. No current delusions or fixed hallucinations. Severe impairment of social functioning. Common sense and judgment are maintained. Calculation ability is not diminished.
6. Auxiliary examination: Outpatient EEG examination in our hospital on 2016-06-20 showed: EEG/BEAM and brain electrical power spectrum within normal limits.

"Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 16 years old.
2. More than 2 years ago, the patient developed persistent sleep problems without obvious triggers, mainly characterized by difficulty falling asleep, with occasional early awakening and daytime fatigue. During this period, the patient occasionally reported low mood but did not experience significant loss of interest or severe impairment of functioning. The patient did not pay much attention to the symptoms and did not receive formal treatment. Current symptoms have not shown significant fluctuation or worsening. Today, the patient came for a general evaluation and denied any negative thoughts.
3. Past history and family history: No special findings.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 88 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 101/66 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice on the skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 88 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness in the abdomen, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention can be maintained, answers are relevant. The patient is appropriately dressed, facial expression is natural, capable of self-care in daily life, normal interaction with the surrounding environment. Insight is partially intact, no evidence of hallucinations was observed. Speech is at a moderate pace, thought is fluent, no disturbance of thought content. Common sense, judgment, comprehension, calculation, and memory are all within normal limits overall.
6. Auxiliary examination: (2016-10-08 ****** District People's Hospital) Cranial ET: Dopamine and other indicators basically within normal range; EEG showed no obvious abnormality.
"

input:
Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is male, 24 years old.
2. Main presentation: The patient has had a significant decline in memory and attention over the past year, with symptoms persisting and progressively worsening. Denies history of hallucinations, delusions, and mood swings.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s usual health status is good. Denies history of epilepsy and other major physical diseases, history of blood transfusion, and infectious disease history. Seven years ago, the patient underwent treatment at ****** Hospital, ****** Town, ****** County.

"Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is male, 30 years old. 
2. Main presentation: 8 months ago, while retrieving files in the records room, the patient experienced excessive anxiety triggered by an enclosed environment, presenting with symptoms such as dizziness, palpitations, dyspnea, tachycardia, and fatigue. Since then, the patient has persistently avoided similar enclosed situations and has been unable to complete daily work duties involving file retrieval, which has significantly impacted occupational functioning. The symptoms only appear in anticipated or actual contact with closed spaces, for which the patient was admitted for further management.
3. Past history and family history: Denies history of hepatitis or tuberculosis; denies history of hypertension or diabetes; nothing else remarkable.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 104 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 124/82 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, and cooperative during examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no palpable superficial lymphadenopathy, neck is supple without resistance, trachea midline, chest is normal, percussion of both lungs produces clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, cardiac border not enlarged, heart rate 104 beats/min, rhythm regular without murmurs, abdomen flat and soft without tenderness, no hepatosplenomegaly, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Orientation is normal, answers are appropriate, voice is low. Appropriately dressed, expression is anxious, initiates contact. No disorders in thought form or content. Insight is basically intact, attention is easily distracted when discussing enclosed environments; descriptions are clear when recalling events. Routine memory, comprehension, and judgment are normal; no hallucinations or illusions.
6. Auxiliary examinations: EEG at ****** Second Hospital on 2016-5-26: within normal limits. Chest X-ray at ****** Third Hospital on 2016-12-25: scant fibrotic foci at left lung apex to be ruled out; pleural thickening at left costophrenic angle, no progression. Cranial MRI on 2017-1-24: no definite abnormalities detected on plain cranial MRI."

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of other specified psychoactive substances, including medications
input: Patient is male, 24 years old. Six months ago, he began using stimulants of unknown origin and gradually developed auditory hallucinations, believing that someone intended to harm or kill him, and claimed that deities in the sky could protect him. The patient described that although he clearly knew it was nighttime, he insisted it was daytime after hearing sounds; when going out, he often felt he was being followed and watched by passersby. Two days ago, due to a sudden feeling of revenge, he attacked a factory, broke glass, and attempted to ignite liquefied gas but was stopped in time. Afterwards, he felt frightened by his own behavior and stated he was unsure why he acted so impulsively. He is extremely prone to anger and losing control over small matters, his speech is increasingly excited, and he firmly believes he possesses exceptional appearance and abilities. Past history reveals a six-month history of using stimulants of unknown origin. Physical examination: vital signs stable, conscious and alert, appropriate responses to questions, no positive neurological signs. Mental status examination shows clear consciousness, accurate orientation, concentration, angry and tense expression, hostile attitude toward medical staff. The patient exhibits definite commentary auditory hallucinations, accompanied by grandiose delusions of ability, persecutory and referential delusions, and lacks insight. Auxiliary examinations have not yet been completed.

"Medical_record_information:\nCase characteristics:\nThe patient is female, 27 years old. Eight months ago, the patient began to worry that seeing people around her cough or sneeze might be related to her own health problems, expressing a persistent fear that she might emit unpleasant odors. This concern intensified at work, believing it might affect patient treatment or worsen her condition, leading to frequent mistakes. The patient often blames herself and has experienced guilt. After reading an online article about masturbation, she became worried about possibly having gynecological diseases, but gynecological examination results were normal. Subsequently, her anxiety shifted to concerns about having issues with her throat. The patient is aware that these worries may lack factual basis but is unable to control such thoughts, repeatedly seeking medical consultations and searching for health information online for reassurance. After receiving psychological counseling, her symptoms were slightly relieved. About 20 days ago, her concerns relapsed, mainly focusing on worries that her nose might emit abnormal odors affecting others. During the course of the illness, there were no hallucinations or delusions. Diet and sleep were normal, daily activities were unaffected, but work ability has gradually declined. The patient’s previous health status was generally good, and she denies any history of major physical illness or family history of psychiatric disorders. Physical examination shows clear consciousness, stable vital signs, and no abnormal physical signs. Mental examination reveals clear consciousness, normal orientation, coherent speech, intact insight, no significant emotional fluctuations, and partially impaired social function."

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. Female patient, 36 years old. 2. Main presentation: (1) Three years ago, after personally witnessing her niece drown, the patient developed persistent panic, with recurrent reliving of her niece's death scene and nightmares. She deliberately avoided any activities that might trigger the memory and spent over ten thousand yuan on forced exorcism to relieve her suffering, resulting in tense family relationships. (2) Two years ago, during pregnancy, the patient experienced persistent hypervigilance, often startled excessively by minor noises, accompanied by significant sleep disturbances, which worsened after delivery. (3) One year ago, the patient was brought by family members to my department for consultation due to impaired social functioning caused by the traumatic event. Electroconvulsive therapy and pharmacological intervention were administered; during treatment, hypervigilance improved and feelings of tension were reduced. The patient discontinued medication on her own half a year ago. (4) Three days ago, while shopping for groceries, due to a crowded scene, the patient suddenly recalled her niece, immediately developed palpitations, shortness of breath, whole-body rigidity, and was unable to continue daily activities. 3. Past history and family history: Five years ago and one year ago, the patient underwent cesarean section at ****** Maternal and Child Health Hospital; one year ago, laparoscopic tubal recanalization was performed. Family denies any history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, or tremor-like physical abnormalities. 4. Physical examination: T 36.5°C, P 84 bpm, R 20 bpm, BP 97/65 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during examination. No jaundice of the skin, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, chest shape is normal. Both lungs are clear to percussion, no crackles, heart rate 84 bpm and regular, abdomen is soft with no tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, no edema in the lower limbs. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention can be sustained over a long period, answers are appropriate, with a tremulous voice. The patient is dressed properly but appears fearful and uneasy, is still able to manage daily self-care, and initiates contact with medical staff. On inquiry, chief complaints repeatedly involve reliving scenes of her niece’s drowning and long-term avoidance of cemeteries and other locations; she specifically reports that trauma has impacted her life comprehensively for over 37 months. No delusional content reported; thinking is coherent without breaks; no records of hallucinations or illusions. Common sense and judgment are normal. Recent memory is significantly impaired, while remote memory is intact. The patient recognizes the connection between her symptoms and the accident, but has difficulty with self-control and has not fully sought medical care. Recently, frequent nighttime awakenings and conflicts highlight increased pressure in family caregiving.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 27 years old.
2. Over 7+ years ago, the patient gradually developed anxiety and tension, experiencing intense anxiety reactions accompanied by dyspnea and feelings of impending death in crowded buses, tunnels, elevators, and other such environments. After outpatient treatment, symptoms partially relieved. The patient actively avoids entering shopping malls, stations, and other public places alone and can only remain briefly when accompanied by relatives and friends. About 3+ days ago, upon entering a shopping mall with family members, a significant fear response was triggered again due to the dense crowd. Throughout the course, there was no manifestation of elevated mood.
3. Past history and family history: The patient experienced parental divorce during childhood, and multiple psychological traumas due to separation from parents in crowded public places. Denies any significant physical diseases or family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: Vital signs are stable; conscious and articulate; no abnormalities in heart, lungs, or abdomen; no positive findings on neurological examination.
5. Mental examination: Orientation is intact, attention is focused, appearance matches stated age. Facial expression is tense and anxious; the patient actively describes excessive fear of public places. No hallucinations or delusions; insight is present but incomplete. Social functioning is significantly restricted due to avoidance of situations.
6. Auxiliary examination: None.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of multiple specified psychoactive substances, including medications
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 15 years old, with an insidious onset and prolonged course.
2. Main presentation: The patient has a history of abnormal behavior 5 years ago, which improved after treatment. In the past month, due to frequent contact with delinquent youths, she has frequently used drugs. After a positive urine toxicology screening, there were significant changes: after drug use, she experienced hallucinations of a decaying face and auditory hallucinations of hearing cats and dogs talking. There was increased persecutory ideation, such as believing her mother and others were trying to harm her, as well as episodes of sitting alone in a daze, bodily stiffness, emotional indifference, and estrangement in family relationships. The patient is aware of the harm of drug abuse but has difficulties with self-control. She had significant mood swings and disordered sleep after discontinuing medication for four months, with a rapid decline in social functioning. Her father brought her for medical attention.
3. Past history and family history: The maternal grandmother has a history of mental illness; no other definite diseases noted.
4. Physical examination: Body temperature 37.1℃, pulse 64 beats/min, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 112/65 mmHg. The patient's consciousness is clear, breathing is steady, responses to questions are partially appropriate, speech is clear, and she is cooperative during the examination. No jaundice on the skin, superficial lymph nodes not palpable or enlarged. Cardiac, pulmonary auscultation and abdominal examination are unremarkable, no pathological reflexes observed.
5. Psychiatric examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is impaired, attention is distracted, voice is low. Expression is blank and indifferent, partially self-sufficient in daily life, volition and motivation reduced, interaction is passive. Poor cooperation, emotional conflict reported, thought content is impoverished, with significant impairment in social functioning. No obvious cognitive impairment detected.
6. Auxiliary examination: Urine toxicology screening is positive.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 22 years old.
2. Main presentation: Since childhood, the patient has exhibited emotional indifference. Parental discord has been longstanding. Over the past 8 years, there has been progressive decline in language ability, with reduced verbal expression and a tendency toward stereotyped speech; at times, coherent sentences are difficult to organize. Daily behavior shows significant deterioration in social skills, with avoidance of interaction with others as the baseline. The patient has been hospitalized multiple times, and pharmacological intervention has provided limited improvement in cognition and behavior. Currently, the patient requires partial supervision in daily life, demonstrates severe lack of initiative, has difficulty executing simple tasks, and often sits quietly all day without spontaneous activity.
3. Past history and family history: There is a family background of neurodegenerative disorders (a grandaunt has a similar history).
4. Physical examination: Vital signs are stable, and cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations reveal no abnormalities. The nervous system exhibits no focal signs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is generally intact. Clothing is poorly organized, and facial expression indicates emotional indifference. Verbal communication is markedly limited; the patient can only respond with simple words and cannot engage in effective dialogue. It is difficult to maintain attention and impossible to complete consecutive instructions. The patient's understanding of common sense and judgment has significantly declined, while calculation ability retains basic numerical concepts. Behavior is stereotyped and repetitive, without self-injury or impulsive manifestations.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 20 years old.
2. Two years ago, the patient had a conflict with her parents and was struck by her father, after which she gradually developed persistent resistance and intense resentment towards her parents. Subsequently, in daily family life, she frequently confronted her parents and siblings, such as having frequent verbal arguments and behavioral opposition with her father. There were incidents where she deliberately provoked family members, for example, splashing cold water on her sister during winter. In the past year, she has mostly lived alone at home, rarely communicates with family members, and spends most of her time attending to online activities and watching television; her self-care ability has generally been maintained. Her family reports that she displays no abnormalities in external social situations and communication with friends. Recently, during a conflict with her father, she had an emotional outburst and threatened to take revenge with a knife. Due to irreconcilable family disputes, she was sent to our department. Upon further inquiry, her family denies any history of seizures, nausea, vomiting, or hemiplegia. The patient also denies a history of hypertension and diabetes.
4. Physical examination: temperature 36.3℃, pulse 78 beats/min, respiration 18 breaths/min, blood pressure 97/63 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing is steady, generally responsive to questions, speech is clear, and she is partially cooperative with routine examinations. Skin is normal throughout, neck is supple without resistance, cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no tenderness or edema, and all physical signs are normal.
5. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, with accurate orientation. Initially resistant during the interview, after brief explanation could describe her experiences of family conflict, but showed significant distraction. When irritable, she expresses dissatisfaction and anger towards authority figures. Dress is neat and appropriate; facial expression habitually displays displeasure. She remains able to care for herself in daily life and does not resist social interactions.
6. Auxiliary examinations: None at present.

Medical_record_information:
Course characteristics:
The patient is female, 23 years old, with a long disease course and slow onset. Eight years prior to admission, when the patient was 15 years old and in her first year of high school, after confessing to her crush, *******, and being rejected, she gradually developed intense feelings of inferiority, feeling excessively nervous and unnatural during interaction with others, displaying stiff movements and speech, and worrying about being disliked or judged by others. She felt that all her classmates were talking about her being strange, thus avoiding contact with others, including her dormitory roommates. Starting two years ago, after graduating from university, the patient avoided going out to work or communicating with outsiders due to fear of social situations, staying at home all day either online or resting. When her parents persuaded her, she felt significantly anxious due to concerns about social evaluation. Four months before admission, her symptoms worsened; after contact with people on that day, she became emotionally agitated and cried, but improved after hospitalization. One day after discharge, she again did not dare to go out due to social anxiety; when communicating with her parents, her anxiety intensified, and she was admitted for further treatment. Her past medical history is normal, denies epilepsy, other major illnesses, and family history of psychiatric disorders. Physical examination shows stable vital signs; the patient is alert, answers coherently, and has no organic abnormalities. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, but displays extreme tension and discomfort during social interaction and avoids eye contact, is capable of self-care, partially possesses insight, emotional disturbance is limited to anxiety in social situations, and there are no obsessive thoughts, hallucinations, or delusions. Common knowledge and judgment are normal. Auxiliary examinations, including routine blood tests, thyroid function, MMPI, and MRI, do not indicate any obvious physical cause.

Medical_record_information: 1. The patient is male, 30 years old. 2. The patient reports excessive worry about his own health that began 4 years ago, with fears of having a serious illness despite multiple medical examinations showing no abnormalities. He frequently complains of vague somatic discomforts such as general malaise and a subjective feeling of fever, though his temperature remains normal. He is persistently preoccupied with health concerns and cannot overcome these anxieties on his own, which troubles him day and night and affects his daily life. He reports poor sleep, resting about 4 to 5 hours per night, but no significant change in appetite. These worries have persisted for years, leading to decreased motivation at work and in social interactions, and repeated medical consultations have not alleviated his concerns. Past history and family history: The patient’s general health is relatively good. He denies history of epilepsy, major physical illnesses, blood transfusions, and infectious diseases. He denies any family history of psychiatric disorders. 4. Physical examination same as above: Vital signs are stable, consciousness is clear, answers are appropriate, cooperative in examination. No positive findings were detected in examinations of all systems. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, dress is appropriate, orientation is normal, initiates contact, answers questions appropriately. Expression is obviously anxious, continuously talks about health worries. Thought shows no formal disorder and no delusional content; mood is dominated by excessive worry, with no elicited loss of interest or depressive mood; common sense, judgment, and comprehension are normal, memory is intact. Social functioning is partially impaired; insight is complete. 6. Auxiliary examinations: On 2012-9-11, routine blood test showed neutrophil percentage at 59.9%, slightly below reference range, but clinically not considered as evidence of organic disease.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 21 years old.
2. Main presentation: Occasionally experiences mild dizziness after emotional agitation, with gradual improvement after rest. Afterwards, she has persistent and strong worries and tension about leaving home, especially when facing crowded places, school, or public transportation. She worries about being unable to escape or experiencing discomfort, and actively avoids going out or is only willing to go out accompanied by peers, which severely affects her schooling and other social activities.
3. Past history and family history: Denies history of epilepsy or other major diseases, and denies family history of mental illness. The patient's mother recalls similar occasional events.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 76 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 114/65 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers questions appropriately, speaks clearly, and cooperates with the physical examination. No jaundice of skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs yields clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate 76 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation normal, attention is easily distracted, answers questions appropriately, voice is low. The patient is appropriately but slightly untidy dressed, facial expression indifferent, good self-care, passive interaction. Significant anxiety can be elicited, no hallucinations, delusions, or other perceptual abnormalities. Common sense, judgment, comprehension, and calculation abilities are normal.
6. Examination at ****** District People's Hospital: ECG and cranial CT showed no obvious abnormalities; cervical spine CT, nasal CT, and TCD were all normal.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours

input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 29 years old.
2. Main presentation: 1) Seven years prior to admission, the patient experienced hallucinations, feelings of being watched and persecuted after using methamphetamine, followed by significant mood fluctuations; 2) Seven months ago, due to lingering effects of the substance, auditory hallucinations and physical discomfort reappeared, including self-harm behavior (head banging against the wall), perceiving people talking about him at a distance, self-reported head pressure and generalized numbness and tingling, and suspiciousness regarding external manipulation.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's general health condition has been average, denies epilepsy and major physical diseases, and denies any family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: Vital signs stable, no positive neurological findings, no abnormalities in heart, lungs, or abdomen.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers are appropriate, facial expression is tense. The patient presents with command and commentary auditory hallucinations, thought echo, and delusional relations, with intact insight.
6. Auxiliary examination: No abnormalities found on electroencephalogram.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of multiple specified psychoactive substances, including medications
input:
Medical_record_information: The patient is male, 33 years old.

Main presentation: Fourteen years ago, the patient experienced abnormal behavior for one episode; details are unclear, management was not specified, and condition later stabilized. Over one year ago, the patient began using methamphetamine and Magu (amphetamine-type stimulant), approximately once per month for about 5 months, resulting in recurrent mood fluctuations and impulsive behavior. During use, there was drug-seeking behavior despite awareness of negative consequences and inability to stop; drug withdrawal caused hand tremors and sweating. Nine months ago, substance use worsened, presenting as disorganized behavior and irritability. Twenty-five days ago, symptoms became prominent; family sought medical treatment due to significant impairment of social functioning.

Past history and family history: The patient generally had average health, and over one year ago was found to have left kidney stones, untreated. Denies history of major physical illness, transfusion, or infectious diseases. No recorded family history of psychiatric disorders.

Physical examination: Temperature 36.3℃, pulse 122 beats/min, respiration 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 146/89 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, and cooperative with the examination. Skin and mucous membranes are normal; no superficial lymph node enlargement. Chest is normal with clear breath sounds bilaterally; heart rate is 122 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat with no tenderness; no edema in lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present; pathological reflexes not elicited.

Mental status examination: Consciousness clear, orientation normal, attention distracted; answers relevant but vocabulary is vague. Appearance matches age, appropriately dressed, anxious expression, capable of self-care in daily life, passive in interactions, lacks insight. Mood is irritable and unstable, no evidence of hallucinations or illusions. Impulsive behavior is marked; social functioning is severely impaired; judgment and comprehension abilities are reduced; calculation ability is average.

Auxiliary examinations: No records available at present.

Medical_record_information:
The patient is female, 24 years old. Over 7 months ago, the patient witnessed her grandmother's suicide, which caused significant psychological trauma. Since the event, she has repeatedly experienced intrusive recollections and nightmares as well as avoidance of discussing topics related to death. About one and a half months ago, due to work-related stress, her symptoms worsened, with daily depressed mood, palpitations and anxiety, and sleep disturbances, often waking up abruptly with hypervigilance. On this visit, the main complaints were anxiety and feelings of helplessness, with occasional hallucinations such as hearing her grandmother calling for help (but recognizing this is not real), episodes of explosive crying, self-injurious behavior after conflict with colleagues, fear of being harmed by family members, and suicidal thoughts but without a concrete plan. Mental examination showed clear consciousness, normal orientation, low voice, focused attention, appropriate responses to questions, no auditory or other hallucinations. Thought content was centered around the traumatic event with frequent suspicion or fear of persecution. General knowledge, judgment, comprehension, and memory were normal. The patient had previously been healthy and denied any family history of mental illness. Physical examination revealed no abnormalities, and auxiliary examinations are currently unavailable. This condition has led to significant impairment in social functioning.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of other specified psychoactive substances, including medications
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 25 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 3 years ago, after taking methamphetamine, the patient developed sensitivity and suspiciousness, fear of being talked about, and significant mood fluctuations (crying and laughing by himself), with occasional impulsive behaviors. The initial consultation was considered to be related to psychotropic substance reaction, and after treatment with olanzapine and clozapine, perceptual abnormalities were basically relieved. During detoxification, the patient took medication regularly. Currently, the patient shows persistent low mood (loss of interest), nervousness (restlessness, palpitations), scattered attention (subjective memory decline), often accompanied by dizziness and other somatic discomforts. Side effects of the medications include dry mouth and transient unclear speech expression.
3. Past history and family history: History of methamphetamine use, currently in detoxification. Denies other physical disease history.
4. Physical examination: Vital signs are stable; no tremor or movement disorders seen in the nervous system; no positive findings in systems examination.
5. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear; orientation is intact; cooperative during contact but lacks initiative. Cognitive function is basically normal; no hallucinations elicited at present; thought coherence is normal; reaction retardation due to medication is present. Mood is obviously depressed, accompanied by anxiety and tension; self-care in daily life is maintained but initiative is reduced. Occasionally pays excessive attention to others' words and actions (such as suspecting being talked about), which can be alleviated by counseling.
6. Additional examinations: Electroencephalogram is normal; brain function testing indicates imbalance in cortical excitability regulation; psychological assessment reveals prominent anxiety and depressive state.

Case characteristics:

In the past 2 months, depressive mood recurred, reduced activity, loss of interest in activities, difficulty falling asleep, repeated suicidal ideation and behavior, and complained of feeling helpless due to excessive restrictions by her parents.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 19 years old.
2. Recently, the patient exhibited confusion in attention and identity, characterized by fixed behavioral patterns and reduced self-control. On the specific day mentioned, the patient was found alone by the riverside, holding personal belongings but unable to recognize their use, and was assisted back to the hospital by others. After being sent by family members, diagnosis and treatment were initiated based on these behavioral issues.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's general health is average, no history of epilepsy, major physical illnesses, blood transfusions, or infectious diseases. No family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 93 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 132/75 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing is steady, and cooperates with the physical examination. No abnormalities in skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations reveal no significant findings, and no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are normal, pathological reflexes are negative.
5. Mental examination: The patient is in a state of altered consciousness, with a narrow response to environmental stimuli, focusing only on specific objects. In speech, the patient misstates her own identity, persistently claiming to be of a young child's age and repeatedly addressing family members with inappropriate titles. Behavior lacks spontaneous variability, presenting a single movement pattern; the patient cannot recall daily events and reports inability to voluntarily control behavioral details. There is currently no expression of mood fluctuations, and interruptions in communication do not affect basic autonomous functioning. Lack of insight.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Cranial CT, chest X-ray, and electrolytes were all normal. Routine blood tests showed mildly elevated leukocytes, but there is no evidence of related physical conditions.

After meals, she routinely induces vomiting to prevent weight gain. Seven months ago, she had a short history of reduced food intake accompanied by weight loss; in the past 2 months, her weight has fluctuated. The patient was admitted for treatment due to difficulty controlling binge eating behavior.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 30 years old, with a long disease course.
2. Ten years ago, the patient experienced a change in behavioral pattern without obvious triggers, manifested as a significant reduction in activity, reduced speech and movement, and occasional urinary incontinence. The patient’s ability for self-care in daily life gradually declined, and activities such as washing and eating required complete supervision by others. She gradually developed impulsive behaviors: repeatedly twisting her own cheeks, spontaneously slapping both cheeks, spitting at will, and purposelessly taking and discarding small items from others. The patient exhibited difficulties in verbal expression, only able to speak fragmented words in daily life. She was hospitalized nine years ago, details unknown, and did not continue treatment after discharge. For more than one year, the patient has been taking “Sanbao capsule” with no improvement. Four months ago, the patient developed spontaneous increase in speech, characterized by mechanical repetition of short sentences, occasional facial expression changes without obvious cause, continuous increase in dependence, resulting in hospitalization.
3. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 75 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 118/85 mmHg. The patient was alert but responded unclearly and was uncooperative with the examination. No organic abnormal signs were found in any systemic examination.
4. Mental examination: Difficult to make contact, indifferent response to external stimuli. Clothing was untidy but no seasonally inappropriate attire observed. Verbal expression was disorganized in word order, limited to word-level responses. Facial expressions changed in an uncoordinated manner. No manifestations of hallucinations, delusions, or mood fluctuations. Unable to perform sequential addition or subtraction within ten, unable to repeat two short sentences, with severe recent memory impairment. Unable to understand basic living instructions, no willingness for treatment.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable at our hospital.

Medical_record_information: 1. The patient is male, 25 years old. 2. Over one year ago, the patient, due to fear of weight gain and poor body shape, began to restrict food intake extremely on his own, manifested as a regular decrease in eating. Early on, he almost fasted completely, later developing intermittent binge eating, while also engaging in high-intensity exercise to control weight. According to the family, the patient repeatedly weighed himself and excessively focused on his body image. Six months ago, the family noticed significant weight loss of about 15kg and urged the patient to eat normally. However, the patient refused, insisting on continuous weight loss, with diet still mainly consisting of low-fat foods. Two months ago, the family noticed the patient developed facial edema, and he sought medical treatment at ****** Second Affiliated Hospital, where he was diagnosed with "emaciation" and received treatments such as liver protection. The edema slightly improved, but eating habits did not change. Later, the edema worsened, and he was referred to ****** Hospital, where enhanced nutrition was recommended but proved ineffective. Recently, the patient's food intake has slightly increased but remains insufficient, with sporadic binge eating episodes, and his overall mental condition is poor. Since the onset, he has had decreased appetite, poor mood, insufficient sleep, and continued weight loss. 3. Past and family history: No history of hypertension or diabetes; the family denies seizures, nausea, vomiting, hemiplegia, or other abnormalities. 4. Physical examination: T 36.4°C, P 62 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 105/71 mmHg. The patient is conscious, communicates coherently, and cooperates actively. No jaundice on the skin or mucosa, no enlarged lymph nodes, heart and lung exams show no abnormalities, abdomen has no tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, and no edema in both lower limbs. 5. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation intact, thinking is clear with no hallucinations, but the patient repeatedly expresses fear of weight gain and persistent concern about being overweight. The patient's clothing is neat but often used to cover and avoid body contact. Self-care ability is good, interaction is proactive, insight is present, and there is no abnormality in value orientation observed. General knowledge, calculation, and memory are not significantly impaired. 6. Auxiliary examinations: Currently unavailable in our hospital.

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is male, 48 years old. 2. For the past 5 years, the patient has developed obvious clumsiness in movement without obvious triggers, with difficulty in daily activities, and irritability accompanied by increased movements. He has a history of long-term outpatient follow-up, and is currently taking 'Zyprexa 10mg qn, Bocisyn 10mg bid, Haloperidol 2 tablets bid, Artane 1 tablet bid' to improve symptoms. Over the past ten days, the family reports worsening of the aforementioned movement coordination issues, with more significant difficulty in self-care. The patient was born prematurely (31+2 weeks, with a twin sister), with a history of birth asphyxia. Cranial CT previously indicated mild intracranial hemorrhage. After school enrollment, he demonstrated poor learning ability and has received long-term motor rehabilitation training. 4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 107 beats/min, R 20 breaths/min, BP 93/61 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, but cooperation with examination is limited. Case characteristics:
