Mood is low but not to the degree of depression, denies suicidal ideation. Thought process is coherent, denies hallucinations or delusions. Partial insight is present.
6. Auxiliary examination: Gastroscopy shows smooth esophageal mucosa, good cardia closure; blood electrolytes: blood potassium 3.4 mmol/L (mildly decreased).

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 35 years old, with insidious onset, long course, and fluctuating condition.
2. Main presentation: More than 2 years ago, the patient began online gambling, initially once a week, later progressing to daily gambling, with symptoms worsening over the past 6+ months. Specific manifestations: The patient reports being unable to control gambling times, frequently stopping work during working hours to indulge in gambling; gambling was of extremely high priority, leading to reduced interactions with family and abandonment of hobbies; despite having accumulated enormous debt, she continued increasing bets and participating online; she often contemplated gambling strategies, and reliving gambling experiences at night caused insomnia. Recently, in order to obtain funds, she lied about medical expenses to borrow money from friends and used her spouse's savings to pay off debts; her work performance significantly declined, and she was dismissed 1+ month ago due to frequent absenteeism. She denies other psychiatric or chronic illnesses, and her family support system has weakened.
3. Physical examination: T 36.3°C, P 82 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 118/76 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice on the skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 82 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness in the abdomen, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
4. Mental examination: Consciousness clear, orientation normal, attention distracted, and when answering questions, the topic repeatedly returns to gambling; voice is tense. Dress appropriate but slightly disheveled, facial expression anxious, partially self-care in daily life, passive social interaction with mild defensiveness in doctor-patient communication. Partial insight present: acknowledges gambling problems but believes she is in control; denies hallucinations and illusions. Speech slightly fast, thought content revolves around gambling; common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension mildly impaired, calculation ability normal, recent and remote memory normal.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 22 years old.
2. For over a year, the patient has experienced periodic episodes of binge eating, typically triggered after stressful events. Each episode involves the consumption of approximately 5000 kcal of food, such as an entire box of cake or a family-sized bag of chips, with complete loss of control during the episode, lasting for 30-60 minutes. Immediately after binge eating, the patient self-induces vomiting. Episodes occur 4-5 times per week and have persisted for 13 months. The patient weighs herself more than three times daily. Despite a height of 163 cm and weight of 51 kg, she continues to restrict her diet. Social activities have decreased by 50% due to fear of others discovering her behavior. She reports intense feelings of shame, a two-level drop in academic performance, as well as difficulties falling asleep and early morning awakening.
3. Past history and family history: Unremarkable.
4. Physical examination: T 36.4°C, P 82 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 112/68 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive and answers appropriately, speech is clear, cooperative with examination. No jaundice on skin or mucous membranes; no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes. Neck is supple, without rigidity or jugular venous distension. Trachea is midline, chest contour normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs yields clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing heard. No cardiac enlargement on percussion, heart rate 82 beats/min, rhythm regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable. Hepatojugular reflux negative. No pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness clear, orientation normal, able to concentrate, responds appropriately though speech is slightly rapid. Wears loose clothing to conceal body shape, appears tense, and repeatedly rubs her hands. Partial insight—acknowledges abnormal eating but avoids discussing body weight. No auditory or visual hallucinations, no persecutory delusions. Thought processes are logical, memory is normal, mildly impaired judgment.
6. Auxiliary examinations: EEG shows mild increase in theta waves; serum electrolytes: K+ 3.2 mmol/L (↓).

English_disease_name: Behavioural or psychological disturbances in dementia
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 30 years old, with a long disease course.
2. Ten years ago, the patient experienced a decline in daily living abilities without obvious triggers, accompanied by memory impairment and other cognitive dysfunctions. She exhibited mutism and reduced movement, with occasional urinary incontinence. Daily life required supervision and care, with difficulties in personal hygiene self-care. Later, abnormal behaviors appeared, such as repeatedly twisting her chin, slapping her face, spitting anywhere, and discarding items after taking other people's belongings, along with disorganized and incomprehensible speech. The inpatient treatment history from nine years ago is unclear, and after discharge, she did not take medication regularly. Over a year ago, she took "Sanbao Capsules" from an unknown source without improvement. The symptoms have fluctuated and worsened over the past ten years. More than four months ago, her disorganized speech and behavior worsened, characterized by occasional excitement, excessive talking, and unexplained laughter, with complete dependence on others for daily living. She was admitted to the outpatient department with a diagnosis of "psychomotor excitement".
3. Physical examination: Vital signs are stable, patient is alert but answers inappropriately and is poorly cooperative during examination. No special positive signs in heart, lungs, or abdomen; limb muscle strength and tone are normal; physiological reflexes are present; pathological reflexes not elicited.
4. Mental status examination: The patient is conscious, passive in interaction, with variable but superficial facial expressions. Emotional fluctuations are obvious and unstable. The content of speech is disorganized and illogical. No hallucinations, delusions, or sense of being controlled elicited. Emotional expression is inconsistent with context. Memory, calculation, understanding, and judgment are significantly impaired. Completely dependent on care for daily life, with no insight for treatment.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

## Admission Diagnosis
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 32 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 1 month ago, without obvious triggers, the patient began to repeatedly bring food back into the mouth within minutes after eating to chew again. After chewing, he often spits the food out or swallows it again. This occurs 5-6 times per week, without obvious nausea or vomiting, but initially such behavior provided relief from tension. Recently, feelings of shame have intensified, and he avoids group meals; accompanied by anxiety, he often excessively worries about work pressure. There is no significant weight loss or symptoms of dehydration.
3. Past history and family history: Mild emotional neglect in childhood, otherwise unremarkable.
4. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 72 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 118/70 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, provides appropriate and clear answers, clear speech, and is cooperative during examination. No jaundice of skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, heart borders are not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 72 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, answers are appropriate, speech is normal in volume and tone. Clothing is neat, expression is anxious, self-care is good, contact and cooperation with surroundings; no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations; no obvious delusional experiences (such as ideas of reference or thought broadcasting), general knowledge, judgment, comprehension, calculation ability and memory are all normal. Patient has partial insight, acknowledges abnormal behavior but lacks active treatment-seeking desire.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Outpatient gastroscopy on 2023-7-15 showed no organic abnormalities. Blood biochemical tests on 2023-7-10 showed normal electrolytes, no signs of dehydration.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 8 years old.
2. Chief complaint: Repeated defecation in non-toilet places for over 5 months. In the past 5 months, the child has defecated on the bedroom floor or inside his school bag 3-4 times per month, and parents often find formed soft stool remaining in his pants. Megacolon and spina bifida have been ruled out at an outside hospital. The child underwent toilet training after age 4, and the parents admitted to frequently punishing him sternly for defecation issues. In the past 2 weeks, due to increased academic pressure with the new school term, the frequency of fecal soiling worsened. There is no history of rectal bleeding or painful defecation, no history of constipation, with daily soft stools. The patient's appetite is normal, sleep is light due to worrying about "dirtying the bed," and his weight is stable.
3. Past history: Delayed language development during kindergarten compared to peers, currently has difficulty reading and problems with attention. Denies any major physical illness or surgical history. No history of convulsions or consciousness disturbances.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8°C, P 78 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 100/65 mmHg. Alert, appropriately responsive but avoids eye contact. No skin or mucosal abnormalities. Heart and lung auscultation negative. Abdomen is soft, without tenderness or masses, bowel sounds 4 times/min. Anal appearance is normal, refuses digital rectal examination, no perianal staining. Muscle strength of all limbs is normal, deep tendon reflexes are symmetrical.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, clothing is clean but suspicious stains on trouser cuffs noted. Interaction is passive; when mentioning defecation events, the child lowers his head and rubs his hands, actively trying to change the subject. No hallucinations or delusions elicited. Admits to "fearing being laughed at by classmates" and refuses to use the toilet during break time, exhibiting avoidance behavior from classroom seat to the toilet route. Judgment is normal, recent memory is slightly impaired.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Colonic transit test, Wechsler Children's Intelligence Scale VIQ82/PIQ88.

Case characteristics: 
1. The patient is female, 35 years old.
2. Main presentation: The patient developed abnormal behavior after experiencing family conflict, characterized by repeatedly entering states of confusion, with a subjective feeling of being completely replaced by a "guardian spirit" which took over her personal identity. During these episodes, she chanted ancient dialect scriptures and performed fixed gestures, with movements appearing rigid and lacking change. After the episodes, she has complete amnesia regarding the possession-type behaviors and can only recall a sense of "being controlled by external forces." These symptoms resulted in loss of work ability and social withdrawal, with significant anxiety. The patient previously visited a community clinic, and was suspected to have an anxiety disorder, but the episodes were involuntary, accompanied by identity replacement experience and a sense of being controlled, so for further diagnostic clarification, she was admitted to ****** hospital.
3. Past history: Denies history of major illnesses such as hypertension and diabetes; denies history of infectious diseases such as hepatitis and tuberculosis; denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7 ℃, P 72 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 118/68 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice on skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, supple neck, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, normal chest shape, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate 72 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, interaction is passive, expression anxious, unwilling to disclose inner experiences during questioning, eliciting relational delusions, sense of being controlled, and identity loss; orientation is intact, insight is lacking, social functioning is severely impaired.
6. Auxiliary examination: Electroencephalogram showed normal EEG; psychological assessment confirmed prominent dissociative symptoms; drug effects and other neurological disorders such as epilepsy were excluded.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
input:
"Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 28 years old, with gradual onset of illness, disease course of 1.5 years, and fluctuating condition.
2. Main presentation: 1.5 years ago, due to work pressure, the patient began online gambling, with progressively worsening inability to control her gambling behavior. She gambled at least 3 times late at night per week and was unable to stop on her own, having attempted to reduce the frequency but experiencing anxiety and irritability. Subsequently, gambling was given priority, and she actively reduced gatherings with friends and personal hobbies to focus on gambling plans. Despite receiving multiple company warnings and eventual dismissal due to lateness and absence caused by gambling, she did not stop gambling and, instead, increased the scale of bets to seek excitement. One year ago, she started deceiving her family to borrow money and misappropriating her partner's savings to sustain gambling, with total debt accumulating to approximately 300,000 CNY. She often gambled to escape when feeling low, stating 'when gambling, everything feels fine,' which led to family relationships breaking down and divorce from her partner. Difficulty sleeping, frequently waking up early and thinking about the next bet, and decreased appetite for nearly 3 months. The patient exhibits partial insight but refuses to acknowledge the seriousness of her problem, with no history of other physical illnesses.
3. Physical examination: T 36.3°C, P 75 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 115/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responds appropriately to inquiries, has clear speech, and is cooperative during the examination. No jaundice of skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, supple neck, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea midline, chest is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs reveals clear sounds, breath sounds clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, cardiac percussion reveals no enlargement, heart rate 75 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
4. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, oriented, has concentrated attention, answers questions appropriately, voice slightly low. Clothing is appropriate, expression slightly depressed, basic self-care in daily life, passive interaction with surroundings, polite to medical staff but resists discussing the impact of gambling. Partially insight, acknowledges having trouble with gambling but underestimates the consequences, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations, no illusions. Speech rate is moderate, thought form: no disorder. Common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension mildly impaired, calculation ability normal, recent memory normal, remote memory normal.
5. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable."

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 28 years old.
2. Main presentation: Four months before admission, the patient experienced low mood after a major work error. Two weeks ago, during a business trip, she developed unexplained panic and episodic amnesia, was unable to recall detailed events of the error, but was able to remember daily minor things. One week ago, she was repeatedly unreachable without reason, found sleeping on the company warehouse floor, and claimed upon waking she did not know where she was, with complete amnesia for the episode. During this period, she mistook a meeting for a rest break, wore pajamas to work, and was noted as abnormal by colleagues. Family members reported a marked reduction in recent social activities, refusal to discuss work topics, and complaints of desks and chairs in the office appearing distorted and unreal.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has generally been healthy, denies history of epilepsy, head trauma, substance abuse, or major somatic diseases. No infectious disease history. No record of mental illness in the family.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 82 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responds briefly but appropriately, and cooperates with the examination. Skin is free of jaundice, lymph nodes are not enlarged, neck is supple with no resistance, heart and lungs have clear sounds without murmurs, abdomen is soft with no tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, neurological pathological signs negative.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, attention is not sustained and distractible, appearance matches age. Clothing is casual yet clean, expression is slightly anxious, partial self-care in daily life such as forgetting to eat, passive interactions, and partial insight. Emotional fluctuations are obvious, crying occurs without cause during interview, no hallucinations or illusions detected. Social functioning is severely impaired; common sense, judgment, and calculation remain normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: CT shows no brain injury, blood test negative for drugs or alcohol.

Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is male, 62 years old.
2. More than 2 days ago, the patient had a fierce argument with his son due to a pension dispute, and after being accused of being "useless," exhibited abnormal reactions. Initially, he sat in silence, then gradually began repeatedly wiping the table surface for 4-5 hours a day. The family noticed no response to calling, and when asked his name and address, he confusedly replied, "I am a cleaner, I need to sweep the street." Three hours before admission, he suddenly began persistently walking in circles, bumping into furniture without stopping, accompanied by muttering, "clean it... must clean it..." The family was unable to stop him and sent him for medical attention. After receiving 1mg lorazepam orally in the emergency department, the stereotyped movements subsided, and he was transferred to the psychiatry department for admission.
Inquiring further about the medical history, the patient's daughter denied history of fever, seizures, or trauma. The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension, denies diabetes and cerebrovascular disease.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 78 beats/min, R 16 breaths/min, BP 148/92 mmHg. Clouded consciousness, uncooperative during examination, maintains passive posture. A 2×3 cm subcutaneous hematoma is visible on the forehead, without open wounds. Heart, lung, and abdominal examination revealed no abnormalities, limb muscle tone is normal, no pathological signs elicited.
5. Mental status examination: Restricted consciousness, only focused on repeatedly wiping the clinic table and chairs. Firmly insists he is a "street cleaner," believes himself to be at a "sanitation station." Affect is flat, no response to calls from family. Continues simulated wiping movements, unable to stop despite persuasion. No hallucinations or delusions detected, partial loss of recent memory but remote memory is retained. Calculating ability and abstract thinking are impaired.
6. Ancillary examination: Head CT indicates mild white matter lesions, other findings currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 26 years old, with an abrupt onset and a disease course of one and a half years, characterized by recurrent fluctuations.
2. Main presentation: 18 months ago and onward, due to academic pressure, the patient developed uncontrollable binge eating episodes, occurring 1-2 times per week, with large amounts of food consumed in 20 minutes each time, far exceeding normal intake; during episodes, the patient felt unable to stop eating or restrict the amount and types of food. After binge eating, the patient immediately engaged in self-induced vomiting and abused over-the-counter laxatives as compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain. The patient is excessively concerned about body shape and weight, often evaluating self-worth based on weight, and despite having a normal BMI, displays a strong fear of weight gain. There are clear psychological distress and depressive mood, leading to social impairment such as decreased work performance. Additionally, the patient has social withdrawal and irritable mood swings. Symptoms worsened one month ago, prompting the visit.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has generally good health. Denies history of epilepsy, major physical illnesses, blood transfusion, or infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 78 beats/min, R 17 breaths/min, BP 122/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and is cooperative during the examination. Skin and mucous membranes show no jaundice, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple without resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 78 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign is negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention can be focused, answers to questions are relevant. Appearance matches stated age, clothing is tidy. Partial self-care, intact insight. No hallucinations or illusions. Mood is low; patient expresses distress about the binge eating pattern and impact on social functioning. Insight is intact, common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension are normal, calculation ability is normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable at our hospital.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 10 years old.
2. Main presentation: After being mocked by classmates for chewing sounds during school lunch, the patient began progressively avoiding most foods, only consuming small amounts of liquids such as dairy products, leading to a weight loss of 2kg over the past 3 months. She presents with significant signs of malnutrition and developmental delay. In daily life, she refuses any solid food and reports a fear of suffocation. After ingesting small amounts of food, she is prone to bloating and nausea, which further exacerbates avoidance behavior. When her mother tries to encourage her to eat, the patient’s anxiety increases; she scratches her arms and shouts, "Don’t force me to eat, I will vomit." There is no concern over body weight or shape.
Past history and family history: During early childhood, she developed a fear of eating after an emergency treatment for choking on hard candy. There is a paternal family history of mild anxiety disorder; the mother denies other genetic diseases.
Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 90 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 105/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, poorly nourished, weight at the 3rd percentile, height 125 cm, respiration steady, fluent responses. Skin throughout the body is dry, mild muscle atrophy of the limbs; neck is supple, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline; chest shape is normal, percussion produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear; heart rate is regular, no murmurs; abdomen is flat, no tenderness; no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present; pathological reflexes are not elicited.
Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is scattered, and she exhibits mild anxiety when answering questions. Clothing is disheveled, facial expression is tense, with high conflict with family; she actively reports being "afraid of hearing eating sounds," but this does not resemble auditory hallucinations, and no delusions are reported; cognitive function is intact. Significant impairment in social functioning: unable to participate in peer activities, lacks insight.
Auxiliary examination: Complete blood count shows mild anemia (Hb 10g/dl); blood chemistry shows hypoalbuminemia (3.0g/L); cranial MRI is normal; EEG shows no abnormalities; ceruloplasmin is normal.

Medical_record_information:
1. The patient is female, 16 years old.
2. Main presentation: Since junior high school, the patient has frequently exhibited aggressive behaviors in both school and family environments, persisting for over 8 months. She often engages in fierce arguments with her mother and teachers over minor matters such as homework assignments or housework tasks, refusing to obey reasonable instructions. For example, she deliberately mocks or makes fun of classmates to provoke others, and when criticized, immediately accuses others of having impure motives. Even minor setbacks trigger intense temper outbursts, averaging 2-3 episodes per week; she is persistently irritable overall and unable to remain calm for more than 1 hour. These symptoms have resulted in academic decline and strained friendships, and her independent attempts at psychological counseling before diagnosis were ineffective. One month ago, her symptoms worsened, with frequent conflicts at school leading to disciplinary suspension. The mother brought her to the outpatient clinic today seeking a systematic evaluation.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s growth and development were normal, with no major somatic disease history or surgical history. Denies infectious disease history and any family history of mental disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 78 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 108/72 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steady, responsive to questions, speech is clear, and cooperative during the examination. No abnormal findings on the skin, no superficial lymph node enlargement, neck is supple without resistance, chest shape is normal, percussion over both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, heart borders not enlarged, heart rate is 78 beats/min, regular rhythm, abdomen is flat without tenderness, no edema in both lower limbs. Normal physiological reflexes, no pathological reflexes elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, contact is acceptable, responses to questions are generally appropriate but frequently interrupted. Attention is distracted, thought process is slightly impulsive, no clear hallucinations or delusions elicited. Mood is irritable and easily provoked; she can quickly switch from calm to anger, affect is hostile. Partial loss of insight, severe impairment of social functioning. General knowledge, comprehension, and calculation abilities are normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Electroencephalogram report from ****** School indicates within normal range; no other auxiliary examinations were performed at outpatient visit.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 28 years old.
2. Main presentation: More than 8 months prior to admission, the patient developed persistent feelings of self-estrangement following work-related stress, feeling as if his body was like a "robot," experiencing emotional numbness and significant mood swings, without marked loss of interest or suicidal ideation. Three months ago, the patient resigned from his job and subsequently felt that the office environment became unreal, with a strong sense of distance as if separated by "glass," making it difficult to focus on work. Over 13 days ago, during a social gathering, the patient suddenly experienced fear, believed the crowd was unreal, became impulsive and requested to leave early, resulting in a quarrel with friends. Later, he was calmed down and sent to a clinic, where he repeatedly reported, "I feel like a bystander" when asked about his experience.
3. On further inquiry, the patient's family denied any exposure to drugs, and denied any history of epilepsy or traumatic brain injury. The patient denied any history of hypertension, diabetes, schizophrenia, or bipolar disorder.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 75 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 122/76 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during physical examination. No jaundice on the skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, supple neck, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea in midline position, chest configuration normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 75 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness in abdomen, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is not focused, answers to questions are relevant, voice is flat. Appropriately dressed and tidy, with a flat affect; partially dependent in daily living, passive in interactions with surroundings, vigilant but not hostile towards clinical doctors. Insight is diminished, no auditory hallucinations, no illusions. Speech rate is moderate, no formal thought disorder, no content thought disorder. General knowledge normal, judgment and comprehension normal, computational ability normal, recent memory is fairly good, remote memory is normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: EEG/MRI examinations are normal; urine toxicology is negative.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 8 years old.
2. Main presentation: Since childhood, the patient has had poor motor coordination, being able to walk independently only at 1 year and 7 months, and even then with unsteady gait and frequent falls. At 3 years old, she was still unable to jump with both feet. During kindergarten, she showed difficulty with buttoning and required adult assistance for dressing. Currently in the second grade of primary school, her handwriting is slanted, messy, and exceeds the grid lines, and her workbooks are often criticized by teachers as dirty and disorganized. She cannot complete basic jump rope actions in PE class, cannot stand on one leg for more than 5 seconds (peers' requirement is >15 seconds), and has repeated falls with bruised knees from riding a children's bicycle. At lunch, she frequently spills food when using a spoon and refuses to learn using chopsticks. Intelligence testing with the Wechsler scale was previously performed at an outside hospital, Wechsler IQ = 95, and cranial MRI showed no abnormalities.
The patient was born premature at 35 weeks of gestation, with a birth weight of 2kg, and an Apgar score of 7 points at 1 minute. No history of epilepsy or traumatic brain injury. The father had a similar history of writing difficulties in childhood.
3. Past history and family history: Denies history of major physical illnesses. The paternal aunt was diagnosed with reading disorder.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 86 beats/min, R 22 breaths/min, BP 88/54mmHg. Patient is alert, cooperative, and fully oriented. Cranial nerve examination is negative. Muscle strength of all limbs is grade V, muscle tone is normal. Coordination: Finger-nose test on the right side is less stable and accurate, rapid alternating movements are clumsy. Balance function: Romberg's sign is negative with eyes closed, but she sways when walking a straight line and needs support. No pathological signs elicited bilaterally.
5. Mental examination: Emotions are slightly anxious, actively describes "most afraid of being laughed at in PE class." Self-reports that papercutting in art class is always uneven. Intelligence is roughly normal, with no hallucinations or delusions.
6. Auxiliary examinations: Weston Developmental Coordination Disorder Test (WetDST) total T score 25 (<40 diagnostic). EEG: within normal range.

diagnostic_category: Disorders due to substance use or addictive behaviours
English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of sedatives, hypnotics or anxiolytics
input:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 38 years old.
2. Due to work-related stress, the patient began using alprazolam for sleep more than 10 months ago, with an initial dose of 0.25mg/d. Due to decreasing efficacy, he self-increased the dosage to 4mg/d, which he has continued till now. In the past 4 months, he developed repetitive speech and frequent mistakes at work. Three days ago, after suddenly stopping the medication, he developed palpitations, hand tremors, vomiting large amounts of gastric contents, and had severe night sweats. He reports "can't remember anything" and refuses contact with colleagues.
3. Past history and family history: The patient has a 2-year history of fatty liver. Denies history of major surgery and infectious diseases. His mother has a history of depression.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 92 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 118/76 mmHg. Patient is alert and cooperative with examination, with fine tremor in both hands. No conjunctival pallor, no cyanosis of lips. Neck is supple, no jugular vein distention. Chest has no deformity, percussion of both lungs is resonant, breath sounds are slightly coarse, no crackles heard. Heart rate 92 beats/min, regular rhythm, heart sounds are muffled. Mild tenderness in the hepatic region (+/-), bowel sounds are slightly increased. Deep tendon reflexes are active bilaterally, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation to time is slightly impaired, and attention is distracted. Expression is flat, emotional response is blunted, self-reports that "life is meaningless." Coherence of thinking is poor, no auditory hallucinations or perceptual disturbances. Partial insight is present; patient admits "there is a problem with medication" but denies need for treatment. Social function is severely impaired.
6. Auxiliary examination: Serum drug concentration testing shows alprazolam level at 276 ng/ml (reference value <50 ng/ml), mildly elevated transaminases (ALT 68 U/L).

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 75 years old. 2. Main presentation: One year ago, the patient suddenly developed slurred speech and weakness of the right limbs, diagnosed as left carotid artery stenosis secondary to ischemic stroke. After thrombolytic therapy and rehabilitation training, muscle strength in the right limbs partially recovered. Over the following six months, she gradually developed cognitive decline, characterized by significant memory impairment, executive dysfunction, decreased language fluency, and visuospatial deficits. Significant mood fluctuations were present, sometimes with depressed mood and social withdrawal. Cognitive impairment accelerated stepwise three months ago, accompanied by inattentiveness and decreased volition. No signs of hallucinations or delusions. First visit to the hospital one week ago. 3. Past history: Hypertension for 10 years, with irregular medication; diabetes for 5 years, managed with dietary control. No family history of dementia. 4. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 72 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 150/85 mmHg. Patient is alert, breathing steadily, slow and relevant responses to questions, speech is slurred. No abnormalities in skin and mucous membranes throughout the body, no palpable enlargement of superficial lymph nodes. Cardiac auscultation: no murmur; both lungs are clear, no crackles; abdomen is soft, no tenderness. Neurological examination: muscle strength grade IV in the right upper limb, grade III in the right lower limb, grade V in the left limbs. Decreased sensation in the right upper limb, Babinski sign positive on the right. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness clear, orientation to time and place intact, attention difficult to sustain, answers are accurate but expression is delayed. Appropriately and neatly dressed, facial expression is flat and stiff, movements are slow. Partial lack of insight, thought form is normal, no delusion or hallucination, mildly impaired judgment, significantly abnormal calculation ability. 6. Auxiliary examinations: Cranial MRI shows bilateral periventricular white matter hyperintensity and multiple lacunar infarctions, supporting vascular etiology; EEG shows mild diffuse abnormality. Alzheimer’s disease is excluded.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 18 years old. The onset was insidious, and the course has lasted for 2 years.
2. Main presentation: Two years ago, the patient began repeatedly biting his lips and buccal mucosa, which has now led to chronic lip ulcers and scarring of the buccal mucosa. The patient reports that this behavior often occurs during periods of significant academic stress or when he is bored and alone; biting provides short-term relief from anxiety, but he is strongly aware of its harmful effects and has tried multiple times to control the behavior without success. Six months ago, he visited the dermatology department due to repeated infections of the lips; after psychiatric assessment, it was determined that the behavior was related to psychological factors.
3. Past history and family history: No significant physical illness history. Family history: the patient's mother had similar nail-biting behavior in her youth.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 78 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, speech is clear, and cooperative during the examination. Examination of skin and mucous membranes reveals crusting and minor ulcers on the lips, and approximately 0.5 cm of old scarring on the inner buccal side; no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, heart, lung, and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities, liver-jugular venous reflux sign is negative.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is relatively focused, answers to questions are relevant, with moderate voice volume. Appearance is normal, but there are frequent subconscious lip-covering gestures; facial expression is mildly anxious, self-care is maintained, and the patient is cooperative with medical staff. Insight is intact, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations or illusions. Clear obsessive-compulsive behaviors and anxious mood can be elicited; speech is slightly rapid; no abnormalities in thought form or content. Memory, calculation ability, and social judgment are normal; partial impairment in social functioning.
6. Auxiliary examination: Outpatient 90-symptom checklist screening: prominent anxiety and obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Brain ET: mild excitatory-inhibitory imbalance, no other obvious abnormalities. EEG is normal.

Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 14 years old. 2. Main manifestations: For 6 consecutive months, she frequently confronted her parents and teachers, refused to complete homework or household chores; frequent intense disputes at home triggered by trivial matters, with emotional outbursts accompanied by door-slamming and screaming; multiple complaints from school about provoking classmates; she reported 'classmates always give me trouble.' In the past 6 months, she has been irritable, suddenly shouting without obvious triggers, and her academic performance has declined significantly. 3. Past history and family history: The patient is in good physical health, denies any major physical illnesses, surgical history, or infectious diseases. Family history: her mother presents with mild anxiety symptoms. 4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 72 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathes steadily, communicates effectively, and cooperates during the physical exam. Skin is free of jaundice, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, trachea is midline, chest wall is normal, percussion of both lungs shows clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, heart borders are not enlarged, heart rate is 72 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is soft, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, no edema in lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are normal, pathological reflexes are negative. 5. Mental status examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, attention is focused, responses to questions are appropriate, clothing is tidy, facial expression appears agitated, self-care is intact, insight is impaired. Emotion: persistently irritable, easily provoked when discussing school rules; no hallucinations or illusions. Social functioning is partially impaired, has tense relationships with classmates, academic performance has declined to the bottom 30% of the class; insight is partially questionable. Common sense, comprehension, and judgment are normal. 6. Auxiliary examinations: EEG: normal waveform. Cranial MRI: no structural abnormalities.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 25 years old.
2. One week ago, due to high-intensity work pressure, the patient stayed up late continuously to complete a project. After the successful delivery of the project, the supervisor suddenly notified the patient of dismissal, causing emotional breakdown. More than 8 hours prior to admission, while working at a desk at home, the patient suddenly experienced shortness of breath, then collapsed on the sofa, with a blank stare and no response to external calls. The patient subsequently cried and intermittently murmured "Who am I? What is my name?", told family members that he was not himself, and repeatedly performed mechanical handwashing over 20 times with no clear purpose. When family members attempted to stop him, the patient shouted "This is not what I want to do!" Emergency services (120) were immediately called and sent the patient to the emergency department. On-site paramedics administered a small dose of sedatives, after which the symptoms partially improved and the patient became slightly aware of his situation. For systematic evaluation, the patient was transferred to a psychiatric specialty; upon outpatient/emergency presentation, he was admitted with "Acute mental disorder, cause to be determined".
    On further inquiry into the medical history, the patient's family denied any history of epilepsy, significant trauma, or underlying cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease. The patient self-reported no history of substance abuse and denied any family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 85 beats/min, R 22 breaths/min, BP 132/88 mmHg. Generally thin, consciousness blurred, slightly rapid respiration, answers sometimes relevant but often irrelevant, slow and unclear speech, poor cooperation. No abnormalities in the head or neck, no trauma marks, sluggish pupillary light response. Heart and lung auscultation normal, abdomen soft without tenderness, slight increase in limb muscle tone, pathological signs negative.
    5. Mental examination: Significant alteration in consciousness, attention fixed on indoor green plants while ignoring inquiries from others. Complete loss of self-identity, repeatedly asking "Which ID card am I on?" and claiming the name is incorrect. Prominent behavioral stereotypy, uncontrollably tapping the desk with repetitive rhythm. Emotional fluctuation is marked, alternating between crying and silence, accompanied by mild anxiety. Denies hallucinations and illusions; lacks insight; intelligence is roughly normal.
    6. Auxiliary examination: Blood routine, EEG, etc., have not yet been reported, suggesting a preliminary exclusion of organic lesions.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 61 years old.
2. Main presentation: The patient suffered an ischemic stroke 3 years ago, confirmed by cranial MRI as a right middle cerebral artery infarction. After thrombolytic therapy, the patient was left with mild walking difficulty, and subsequently developed gradual cognitive decline. Beginning 1.5 years ago, the patient exhibited marked memory impairment and severe executive dysfunction, along with unstable attention and decreased speech fluency. Six months ago, significant mood fluctuations and reduced social interaction appeared, accompanied by visuospatial dysfunction. While the patient has a recurrent cerebrovascular risk, there has been no acute episode this time. Two weeks ago, the family noticed unexplained refusal to eat and nighttime depressive episodes, and thus brought the patient to ****** hospital for medical consultation. The patient denies psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations and delusions.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7°C, P 82 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 130/85 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing is even, answers are basically appropriate, and cooperates with the physical examination. Skin throughout the body is normal, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, chest shape is normal, lungs are clear on auscultation with no crackles, cardiac borders are not enlarged, heart rate is regular with no murmurs, abdomen has no tenderness or rebound tenderness, no edema in the lower limbs.
Neurological signs: muscle strength is normal in the left limbs, right hemiplegia, decreased sensation on the right side of the body, and positive Romberg sign.
5. Mental examination: The patient is conscious, has intact orientation, difficulty concentrating, no disturbance in thought process, no hallucinations or illusions; however, disturbances in thought content are present, such as referential delusions; speech fluency is insufficient, memory is significantly impaired, executive dysfunction is present; partial insight; emotional instability.
6. Auxiliary examination: Cranial MRI shows multiple ischemic infarcts, extensive white matter hyperintensities, and periventricular demyelination; EEG suggests mild to moderate generalized slow wave abnormalities.

Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 28 years old.
2. Main presentation: During work, the patient frequently suddenly enters a dazed state, feels as if his soul is occupied by that of a senior colleague at the company, and speaks in a deeper tone and commanding manner, guiding coworkers through impossible sales tasks. After awakening, he is unable to recall his behavior during the trance, sometimes only remembering fragmented pieces. During episodes, he intensely focuses on sounds of shooting or flickering lights, forgetting the surrounding environment. He experiences dramatic mood swings, such as sudden anger or crying in meetings without apparent cause, which has led to repeated work mistakes and warnings from his boss. He feels as if his soul is forcefully ejected from his body by an external force and loses control of his actions; for example, he may suddenly perform strange business gestures. Last week, in a coffee shop, he sat with legs apart and talked to himself for half an hour; customers complained afterward. His functional ability is impaired: social avoidance, refusal to attend gatherings with friends, more than 30% decrease in work efficiency.
3. Past history and family history: Previously healthy, with no significant physical illness history. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.5℃, P 78 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 116/76 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the physical examination. No jaundice on the skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is in the midline, chest shape is normal, no widened intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs produces clear sound, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing sounds, no heart enlargement on percussion, heart rate is 78 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness in the abdomen, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular venous reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is sometimes scattered, answers to questions are relevant, tone is slightly agitated. Clothing is appropriate, facial expression is indifferent, basic daily self-care but decreased communication with family; passive interaction but cooperative with the examiner. Insight is lacking; no auditory hallucinations; no illusions. Speech rate is relatively fast. Thought disorder: present, with loosened associations; thought content disorder: present, including control delusions and identity substitution delusions. General knowledge is normal, judgment and comprehension are mildly impaired, calculation ability is normal, partial loss of recent memory, remote memory is normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is female, 72 years old. 2. Main presentation: The patient was hospitalized 5 years ago due to acute cerebral infarction, and was diagnosed with right basal ganglia infarction. After thrombolytic therapy, mild left limb weakness remained. Cognitive function gradually worsened since then, showing a stepwise progression. Two years ago, significant memory decline occurred, frequently forgetting recent events such as family phone conversations, accompanied by executive dysfunction, manifesting as inability to independently complete daily planning such as managing household affairs. One year ago, marked emotional fluctuation was noted, with periods of depression and crying, irritability and abusive language, and reduced social activities with no further participation in community events. In the last half year, concentration became difficult to maintain, with easy fatigue and clumsier language expression, difficulty in naming common objects, and occasional spatial disorientation. The patient underwent assessment at an outside hospital, and Alzheimer's disease and Lewy body dementia were excluded. One month ago, due to sudden aggravation of symptoms, cognitive function deteriorated sharply, with obvious disorientation and decreased volition, the patient became unable to care for herself in daily life and was brought for medical treatment by family members. 3. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 82 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 140/90 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers partially relevant, speech is slightly slurred, cooperative during examination. Skin and mucous membranes throughout the body are normal, no palpable enlarged superficial lymph nodes. No abnormalities of the head, neck is supple without resistance. Cardiopulmonary auscultation revealed no murmurs, abdomen showed no tenderness. Neurological signs: mild left hemiparesis and decreased sensation on the left side, left limb muscle strength grade IV, right limb muscle strength grade V. Right upper limb ataxia positive, Babinski sign left (+). 4. Psychiatric examination: Consciousness is clear, mild decrease in orientation, attention is not focused. Significant memory impairment. Emotional fluctuations: sometimes anxious, sometimes indifferent. No hallucinations or illusions. Slow speech, normal thought content. Common sense partially impaired, decreased judgment, impaired computational ability. 5. Auxiliary examination: Cranial MRI report shows bilateral multiple infarcts, extensive white matter hyperintensity, and subcortical atrophy; EEG suggests moderate diffuse slow wave activity.

"Case characteristics: 1. The patient is male, 28 years old. 2. Main presentation: (1) The patient developed persistent geophagia (eating soil) 3 months ago, occurring 2-3 times per week, unable to control himself, and found it difficult to stop despite repeated education. This behavior is not related to cultural customs. (2) At the same time, the patient presented with a severe aversion to normal foods, only taking in small amounts of liquid diets, resulting in a 5 kg weight loss and fatigue. (3) The patient has a background of moderate anxiety disorder and self-reports being aware of the harmfulness of the behavior but unable to resist the psychological urge, accompanied by a reduction in daily social activities. 3. Physical examination: T 36.6℃, P 78 beats/min, R 16 breaths/min, BP 125/80mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and is cooperative during the examination. The complexion is pale. Chest shape is normal, no enlargement of intercostal spaces, percussion shows clear sound in both lungs, breath sounds are clear, no crackles, no wheezing. The patient is neatly dressed but appears mentally fatigued, facial expression is depressed, highly guarded toward medical staff, partial insight. 6. Auxiliary examinations: currently unavailable."

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is a 31-year-old male.
2. Main presentation: Over 8 years prior to admission, during military service, the patient repeatedly experienced extreme threat events such as battlefield explosions and captivity, exhibiting recurrent intrusive flashbacks and vivid re-experiencing of trauma scenes, with nightmares 3–4 times per week themed around being chased or attacked. The patient actively avoids military news and related places, is highly vigilant to loud noises or crowds, and has light sleep and is easily awakened. Persistent negative emotions are present: intense guilt ("I should have saved him"), feelings of helplessness, and shame. Ten days prior to admission, a social gathering triggered a panic attack manifested as whole-body trembling, shortness of breath, chest tightness, lasting about 5 minutes, alternating with emotional numbness and outbursts, stating "I'm worthless, no one can be trusted." 
3. Medical history: The patient's family denies any history of epilepsy or major physical illnesses. The patient denies history of hypertension, diabetes, or other chronic diseases.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 75 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 110/65 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and cooperates with the examination. No ecchymosis of the skin, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline. Chest is symmetrical, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing. Cardiac borders are not enlarged, heart rate is 75 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs. Abdomen is soft, without tenderness or rebound tenderness, no palpable enlargement of liver or spleen, hepatojugular reflux sign is negative, and no edema in both lower limbs.
5. Mental examination: The patient's consciousness is clear, orientation is intact, attention is focused but briefly distractible, answers questions appropriately, and voice volume is normal. Dress is clean and appropriate, expression is tense, with passive interaction with surroundings and strong defensiveness toward medical staff. No disturbance in thought form, but manifestly negative self-appraisal ("I am a failure"). Complains of multiple somatic discomforts (such as gastrointestinal disorder). Common sense, comprehension, judgment, and memory (cognitive functions) are normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Not available at ****** hospital.

Medical_record_information: Case characteristics: 1. The patient is male, 14 years old. 2. Main presentation: Persistent oppositional behaviors have occurred frequently in family and school environments for 7 months, including refusal to complete academic tasks, throwing and smashing objects and shouting loudly when parents request study, deliberately disrupting classroom discipline to provoke teachers, repeatedly accusing classmates of "deliberately mocking him"; even minor criticism triggers emotional outbursts, and a physical conflict occurred after his deskmate touched his stationery. Social relationships are impaired, with no stable friends; academic performance dropped by two grades during the semester. 3. Past history and family history: The patient has no history of major physical illnesses. He had a history of febrile convulsions at age 2, which has resolved. No other infectious disease history or surgical history. His uncle has a history of anxiety disorder, and his parents deny any psychiatric history. 4. Physical examination: T 36.6°C, P 75 beats/min, R 19 beats/min, BP 110/70 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, speech is logically coherent, cooperative during examination. No jaundice or petechiae on the skin, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, trachea is midline, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear on auscultation, cardiac borders are not enlarged, heart rate is 75 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs heard. Abdomen is flat and soft, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated below the costal margin, shifting dullness is negative, no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are brisk; pathological signs not elicited. 5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is accurate, attention can be focused, responses are appropriate, appearance matches age. The patient is neatly dressed, has a tense expression and a guarded attitude, with full self-care in daily life. Affect: Irritable state with frequent angry expressions. Insight is partial, and no hallucinations or delusions detected during perception check. Social function assessment: Peer relationships are markedly impaired, academic functioning is moderately impaired. Accumulation of general knowledge, judgment, and comprehension are consistent with age, calculation ability is normal. 6. Auxiliary examination: EEG: Slightly poor modulation of alpha rhythm, no epileptiform discharges observed. Cranial MRI scan: All ventricles are symmetric, no abnormal signals in brain parenchyma. Psychological assessment scales indicate impulse control deficits.

English_disease_name: Disorders due to use of cannabis
input:
Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 29 years old.
2. Main presentation: One year ago, the patient began intermittent cannabis use, which progressed to daily use six months ago. After using cannabis, she experienced euphoria and relaxation but also had difficulty concentrating, memory impairment, and slowed thinking; upon cessation, she developed withdrawal symptoms such as irritability, insomnia, and decreased appetite. She consistently attempted to reduce use but was unsuccessful, spending excessive time acquiring and consuming cannabis, leading to frequent lateness at work and significantly reduced social activities.
3. Past history and family history: Beginning cannabis use in 2022, with a cumulative history of one and a half years; no family history of psychiatric disorders or substance abuse.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8°C, P 102 beats/min, R 18 breaths/min, BP 122/79 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing stable, answers appropriately, speech clear, and cooperative during examination. No jaundice of the skin or mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distension, trachea is midline, chest without deformity, percussion of both lungs yields clear sounds, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezing, heart borders not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 102 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is soft without tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, no edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, dressed neatly, with an anxious expression, basically self-sufficient in daily living, passive in interactions, relatively indifferent response to medical staff. Orientation is normal, answers appropriately. Mood is labile with significant anxiety. Volitional activity is reduced, no speech or formal thought disorders. Thought content disorder: no hallucinations or delusions. General knowledge is normal, mild decline in judgment and comprehension, calculation ability is normal, remote memory is normal, mild impairment in recent memory, partial loss of insight, moderate impairment in social functioning.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

"Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 24 years old.
2. Main presentation: The patient reported that half a year ago, after witnessing a fire in his apartment building that resulted in casualties, he gradually developed recurrent nightmares and re-experiencing of the fire scene, with a frequency of more than four times per week. When hearing fire engine sirens in daily life, he developed whole-body stiffness and profuse sweating. Over the past three months, he has actively avoided high-rise buildings and enclosed spaces, moving to a single-story house to live alone. His mood has been persistently low, with the course exceeding six months. He expresses self-blame for being a 'guilty survivor', has had 3 episodes of explosive rage in which he smashed and broke objects, each lasting about half an hour and followed by immobility and sitting in a daze. Somatic symptoms include difficulty falling asleep and persistent neck and shoulder pain. Two weeks ago, after a coworker patted him on the shoulder, he suddenly screamed and squatted defensively, and was unable to continue working. Social functioning: resigned from his job and cut off contact with relatives and friends.
3. Past history and family history: During childhood, the patient experienced persistent physical abuse from his biological father and long-term absence of protection from his mother. Denies substance abuse. Previous history of anxiety disorder for two years. Negative family history.
4. Physical examination: T 36.8℃, P 102 beats/min (resting), R 22 breaths/min, BP 130/85 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed resting tremor in both upper limbs; otherwise, no abnormalities found. Psychiatric examination: clear consciousness, intact orientation, and cautious in interaction. During Q&A, he repeatedly rubbed his hands and scanned for escape routes. He self-reported 'I am defective and unworthy of love', and when mentioning childhood events suddenly responded to questions in a childlike voice. One episode of flashback was elicited, during which he cowered in the corner, trembled, covered his head and shouted 'Don't hit me'. Reality testing was partially impaired; partial insight present.
5. Auxiliary examination: CAPS-5 scale score 78 points (meets the criteria for severe C-PTSD)"

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is male, 55 years old.
2. Main presentation: Two and a half years ago, after the patient's wife died of cancer, the patient developed extreme longing for the deceased every day, often talking to her photographs alone, unable to engage in normal social activities, and unable to accept his wife's passing. He repeatedly suspected "misdiagnosis, she might still be alive." Emotional distress was manifested by persistent sadness and guilt, frequently blaming himself: "Why didn't I find the cancer cells earlier?" He experienced confusion about self-identity, stating, "Without her, my life is meaningless," and repeatedly avoided places related to the deceased. For the past year, he has had persistent loss of appetite, sleep disorders, and a significant decline in work ability. His social functioning is severely impaired, self-care in daily life is poor, and he once briefly experienced visual hallucination of the deceased, claiming, "I felt her presence on the bed," although insight was intact. To date, symptoms have not been alleviated.
3. Past history and family history: The patient's overall previous health status was relatively good. Denies history of heart disease, diabetes, other major physical illnesses, blood transfusions, or infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.3℃, P 78 beats/min, R 19 breaths/min, BP 125/75 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steadily, responsive to questions, with clear speech, and cooperative during the examination. No jaundice on skin and mucous membranes, no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple, no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs clear, breath sounds clear, no rales or wheezing sounds, heart boundary not enlarged on percussion, heart rate 78 beats/min, regular rhythm, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpated, liver-jugular vein reflux sign negative, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes present, pathological reflexes not elicited.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is adequate, answers to questions are relevant. Appearance: looks aged. Clothing is somewhat untidy, facial expression is depressed, self-care in daily life is incomplete, insight is intact. Emotion: depressed mood accompanied by anxiety, emotional response is slow, no auditory hallucinations; no other hallucinations, no illusions. Social functioning is significantly impaired. Insight: complete; common sense is normal, judgment and comprehension are partially impaired with vague awareness of death, calculation ability is normal.
6. Auxiliary examination: Currently unavailable.

Medical_record_information:
Case characteristics:
1. The patient is female, 28 years old.
2. Since more than half a year ago, following a cesarean section, the patient has persistently felt unwell, mainly manifesting as excessive concern about her health and the belief that she has contracted a serious illness. Specifically, she frequently worries about having HIV, has undergone HIV screening at multiple hospitals, with repeatedly negative results, but the patient persistently refuses to believe the test results and firmly believes she is ill, also fearing that she will transmit the disease to her child. At the same time, she is overly concerned about her family’s health and is sensitive to the surrounding environment. She has previously received treatment at ****** Hospital, with sertraline 100mg qd and quetiapine 200mg qn, and her medication compliance has been good. Three days ago, her health concerns intensified, accompanied by mild physical discomfort.
3. Past history and family history: The patient’s usual health status is average. Denies history of epilepsy and other major physical illnesses, blood transfusion, and infectious diseases. Denies family history of psychiatric disorders.
4. Physical examination: T 36.7℃, P 78 beats/min, R 22 breaths/min, BP 112/78 mmHg. The patient is alert, breathing steady, answers appropriately, speech is clear, and cooperates well during physical examination. No jaundice of skin and mucous membranes, no enlarged superficial lymph nodes, neck is supple with no resistance, no jugular vein distention, trachea is midline, chest is normal, no widening of intercostal spaces, percussion of both lungs is clear, breath sounds are clear, no crackles or wheezes heard, cardiac percussion shows no enlargement, heart rate is 78 beats/min, rhythm is regular, no murmurs, abdomen is flat, no abdominal tenderness or rebound tenderness, liver and spleen not palpable, negative hepatojugular reflux sign, no pitting edema in both lower limbs. Physiological reflexes are present, pathological reflexes are absent.
5. Mental examination: Consciousness is clear, orientation is normal, attention is focused, responses to questions are appropriate, and appearance matches age. Clothing is appropriate, facial expression is worried, average self-care in daily life, partial insight. Mood is disturbed by health concerns, no auditory or other hallucinations, no illusions. Significant impact on social functioning, with decreased interpersonal communication and work ability. Common sense, judgment, comprehension, and calculation are normal.
6. Auxiliary examinations: No relevant results currently available in our hospital. ****** Hospital (2013-04-01) report indicates abnormal urine routine, with positive protein and bilirubin, positive anti-SS-A autoantibody, and decreased complement C3. Other tests such as liver function, blood lipids, biochemical tests, fasting blood glucose, renal function, tumor markers, thyroid function, glycated hemoglobin, immunoglobulin, ceruloplasmin, routine blood test, fecal routine, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are all normal. No abnormalities found in cranial MRI, EEG, abdominal ultrasound, or ECG.
